 Steamworks is here, the great tyrant GFWL is dead and gone! A round of applause is in order for Nordic Games for reviving this wonderful game. Now, on with the review.	 Red Faction: Guerrilla is an insanely fun game, let's get that out of the way right now. The open world nature combined with the destructable nature of almost every structure in the game makes for one of the most enjoyable, destructive romps you'll ever have in a game. While you play through the story mode you'll have a wealth of options for how to deal with objectives, many of which involve the destruction of key buildings. Perhaps you'd like to get up close and personal with your hammer, maybe you'd rather hop in a truck and send it flying through the side of a building or you might just hail it with rockets from afar, all of which are perfectly viable options.Even if you don't wish to go through the campaign it's likely you'll find enjoyment in one of the two other gametypes:Wrecking Crew - A Solo or Local co-op gamemode with leaderboard integration where you seek to do as much damage to the buildings in a give map with different caveats depending on the mode which are: Total Chaos - Doing as much damge as possible in one minute with unlimited ammo. Behemoth - Using one of three Walker (mech) types to do as much damage as possible in a limited time. Challange - Completing level-specific challanges. Escalation - You have a limited amount of time and ammo, each round both increase. Barrel Dash - Destroying as many explosive barrels as you can within the time limit. Rampage - Deal as much damage as possible with a three minute timelimit, each shot or swing of your weapon takes a set amount of time away.Internet Game - Go head-to-head with other players in a variet of gamemodes, such as: Anarchy / Team Anarchy - Your basic Deathmatch mode. Bagman / Team Bagman - Hold the bag and gain points. Capture the flag - Exactly what it says on the tin. Siege - Defend / Attack gamemode where the key is to destroy specific structures. Damage Control - Fight to capture the three points. Demolition - Protect the Destroyer, the only person who can damage buildings as they go around and destroy as much as they can.TL:DR - The Pros New Direct X11 support, improved stability, better experience over all thanks to Nordic. New steamwork intergration, including Matchmaking and achievements. Strong openworld campaign with plenty to keep you busy. A host of other activities beyond the campaign that provide many hours of fun. You can load up a truck with remote mines, send it flying into the side of a building and then detonate it. Awesome.The Cons Known technical issues, check the forums and such to see if it'll have any issues with your setup. Many of these are being fixed by Nordic currently, it would seem. Still, it's good to make sure. While the campaign is fun and story is perfectly acceptable, anyone looking for a great narrative might find it lacking.

Posted: December 5, 2013
												   It's very sad and disappointing how this game wasn't really given a chance due to mediocre reviews from popular media sites.  OK, this game has flaws;  The AI isn't bad but also nothing special, the behavior coding is pretty poorly done with followers walking in front of you while you are aiming and firing as well as running in front of your vehicles while you try to make getaways, and the game can get slightly repetitive.  HOWEVER, as Craig put it, Red Faction Guerilla is truly masterful at destruction.  The first true "Next Generation" feeling of awe I felt was from this game when I destroyed my first structure.  After I finished with it, I watched as it groaned while trying to support itself under its own weight then eventually crumbled beautifully into a glorious pile of scrap.  I don't think I have ever felt as truly satisfied than when I "stuck it to the man" in teh form of a giant mining truck plowing through military controlled compounds, watching architecture collapse all arounds me as I literally drove into then out of large structures.  If you have the capacity to be moderately creative, and teh rig to handle that "creativity" (I would recommend 512+ VRAM, though you can run this game at 256 on lowest, at least I had to for a while) then, as someone who has actually logged a respectable amount of playtime, I cannot describe this game in any other way than a "work of art."  I would say it's easily worth 20$, a steal if you get it under, like I did...

												Red Faction Guerrilla is Blow Stuff Up: The Game.You can destroy everything. And I mean everything. There are literally like two buildings in the entire map that you can't blow up, and it's only because they're integral to the plot or a mission element. Everything else is at your mercy. You can decide, at absolutely any time in the game, to punch a hole in the nearest wall with a supercharged sledgehammer. And I think that's really the essence of RF:G. You have absolute and complete freedom with the environment you're put in. It's a true sandbox; there is nothing you can't put a few explosives on and demolish when the mood takes you. It's never the case such as in other games, where there's occasional missions to sabotage things and the rest of the time it's like "LOLNOPE, THIS WOODEN SHACK IS INDESTRUCTABLE, RAM AS MANY CARS INTO IT AS YOU WANT LOLOLOLOLOLOLO" It's never that. The game never cuts you off with the mission focus, either. The entirety of Red Faction Guerrilla is built around the mechanic of destructable environments. What do you do in missions? You sabotage enemy bases, or demolish buildings to cover the Faction's tracks, or ram a car into this, or fire a thermobaric rocket at this big hydrogen tank thing. How do you unlock new missions? You smash the f*ck out of enemy bases to lower enemy control over the sector, and raise morale. And with the variety of it all, and the many methods of nuking an EDF outpost, and being able to dismantle every single piece of a checkpoint until nothing is left; it's just intoxicating.Not to mention: THERE ARE CHEATS. You can be an invincible super-badass and propel cars with melee attacks into buildings and run super fast and and and---Even in the moments where you're not giving Martian architects the finger, the game remains solid, and combat is enjoyable and challenging. It's never a case of running in like Superman and obliterating an entire army with your bare fists; you have to find yourself some cover and demolish the enemy's; choose the right weapons for the right situations, and be accurate. Ammo conservation is a big part of fighting EDF soldiers, so spraying plasma bullets everywhere isn't going to earn you victory. Story's pretty nice, too, but it's more just to support the gameplay; the main attraction is the explosions and destruction.TL;DR: Breaking things is fun. This game is all about breaking things, so this game is fun, and you should buy it.

Posted: April 19, 2015
												GTA on Mars? Well, it may be a little too far-fetched, but it still is true. You have this HUGE map with tons of missions and tons of DESTRUCTIBLE buildings. And the game wants you to cause mayhem and destruction. No mission can be completed without wreaking havoc!The story is mediocre at best: you play a guy called Mason whose brother has just died. He takes up his role working for the guerrilla, a rebellious group that aims to rid Mars of the oppressive government called EDF. There are some nice cutscenes telling the story but the 20 main missions are not sufficient to make it a great story.On the other hand: Who cares? The story is just an excuse to destroy everything in your path. As you make progress further areas open up in front of you with the same goal: you must liberate them. Every sector has a morale meter that increases as you complete missions. Higher morale means more assistance from guerrilla members while fighting. Main missions that advance the story can be accessed, too, with the exception of the last one. This particular mission to liberate the sector requires you to decrease enemy morale. Naturally, helping the rebels causes the bad guys lose morale.Do you like collectibles in games? Well, Red Faction has destructibles. You can prove your worth by looking for high value EDF buildings, piles of ore, propaganda signs and practically anything else that belongs to Mars' evil faction. Side missions are also many and varied as one would expect: you can catch couriers, protect allied areas, take vehicles to safe locations or - and this is my favourite - ride shotgun with Jenkins. The guy drives but you are manning the gun: just shoot at everything that belongs to EDF - buildings, vehicles and anything that increases the counter on the upper right-hand side of the screen telling you how much damage you have caused. Once you have reached 1 billion credits another achievement pops up.I like how varied the environment is. You would think the entire game swims in brownish-reddish colours. No! New sectors have a newer, more different look. Oasis has green areas with fewer but bigger buildings telling you this is where the upper class of Mars lives. The Badlands have a more evil look with the presence of the mysterious marauders - you can clearly see this is an homage to Mad Max!A good way to encourage the player to cause destruction is the currency introduced: every collapsed building leaves scrap metal. These shiny, light blue pieces of salvage can then be used to buy newer weapons or upgrade the existing ones. I understand the Steam Edition of the game has a lot of new features. This is certainly a plus - I played this well after it finally ditched the awful GFWL service. It is a good thing that more and more games do the same! To summarise: Red Faction is a game about destruction. There's nothing more satisfying than leaving the office after a long and hard day and using Mason's sledgehammer to off some Martian bad guys or to destroy a tower. And if you truly want to destroy everything dozens of hours of fun is guaranteed!

Red Faction: Guerrila Review - Rating: 8.7/10General ImpressionRed Faction: Guerrilla is a very nice open-world destruction game. From my point of view, would be a nice Grand Theft Auto: Mars Edition. That’s because it is an extremely open-world game, being a huge advantage. I had a lot of fun with this game. Off to the features: The graphics are well-designed, everything has a smooth looking, there were a lot of items which needed to be polished, and the developers proved to do it pretty nicely. The textures are nice and well-made. The atmosphere varies between 7 different environments, where the buildings will change, the enemies will be tougher and more, the sky’s and the overall map will look quite different (the color, sometimes it’s more windy, etc.) It’s a really nice atmosphere, indeed some places are not lively, but good morning, this is Mars, what did you expect? It’s realistic. The audio is nice, everything sounds well, the voice acting, the cars’ sounds, the tanks’ sounds, the guns’ sounds, etc. They were made to sound pretty realistic as well. The music is a nice feature as well, the music changes from the point where you are not in a combat status, where an ambient music will play, and when you will combat, a dynamic music will play. Hence there aren’t many types of music, they are all well-made, and I appreciate that. The gameplay is a pretty strong point. This game is open-world. You have many side quests, such as reaching a location in a matter of time, or destroying a location in a matter of time, saving arrested citizens, and also unexpected side missions, where you will have to go to a base and defend from the EDF. The main quests will generally come consecutive, meanwhile sometimes you will need to go to a certain location to activate the mission, or you need to get the maximum respect from the citizens of the respective area in order to unlock the last mission of the area, as example. Salvage is also a very important feature, by collecting salvage you can upgrade guns or buy new ones. The story is well-thought, and you will constantly experience it throughout the game. The user-interface is well-designed, and also it has additional designing and synthetized information. The controls are very well-chosen, all of them are easy-to-learn and good. The engines are alright, I haven’t found any haven’t met any bugs, crashes, screen freezes or frame drops. On bad computers, you will experience easy lagging, hence I actually didn’t. The mechanics… we need to talk more about this one here. Destruction. That’s what would resume the mechanics. There are so many ways to kill your infantry enemies, your vehicle enemies, your tank enemies, any building, and even other elements. Buildings, especially… have a very complex way of destruction. They destruct in a very realistic way. All the damage given to them is as it should be, nor too low, nor too high. The characters move well, the cars are fast and feel very good when driving them, and even other positive elements. Overall, Red Faction: Guerrilla is a great open-world destruction simulator, with nice graphics, awesome gameplay, interesting story and sophisticated mechanics.Positive PointsNice and well-designed graphics and texturesLarge and different atmospheresPretty nice audio and musicAwesome, fun and challenging gameplayMany main and side quests availablePurchasable guns by salvage itemsAn interesting storyWell-designed user-interface with additional designsWell-chosen controlsPretty stable enginesSophisticated mechanicsSteam achievements and trading cards available Neutral PointsSome racing missions would be a nice featureBeing able to talk to people would also be a nice featureNegative PointsThe multiplayer is not alive anymore, a big disadvantageSome missions are pretty uninteresting, such reaching a point with your car in a certain amount of time

 A short history of RF:G No I am not going to spell out its full name because I cannot properly spell Guerrilla. Its double R and double L I know but no. No full name. Anyways back to the history, RF:G was originally released with Games With Windows Live integrated. That means no cheats, lots of issues regarding login and etc etc and we have tons of weird graphical problem that made this game not very well known. Thankfully the Steam port has been optimized and there is no more GFWL. Thank god. My pc went from 20fps to 60 stable fps. Game Info Name: Red Faction : GuerrillaDeveloper: A lot of people, this game has been brought out by Nordic Games after the fall of THQ. RIP.Genre: Smasing, Action, Open World, Guerrilla WarfarePersonal Thoughts: Good game although there are parts that they did right and parts that they did wrong. What is Red Faction: Guerrilla? A game about a guy who lost his brother and so join a rebel insurgency fighting back against the military. ON MARS! That means super wonky vehicle, unrealistic weapons and building that crumbles at the drop of a hat. Everything you see saved for some things are completely destructible using the force of vehicle, hammer and explosive! But dear god the story is wonky even though it make sense like the Dev tried stretching a lump dough too thinly trying to cover the whole baking table with it. But well at least the game is fun enough to cover that slight defect.  Sound Main character grunts a lot, gun doesn't pack any power in them although we can excuse it by saying in the future recoil proofing technology has improved. The most powerful anti infantry still sounds like the usual sci fi pew pew pew. Hardly any music in this game but one good thing is at least vehicle grunt properly instead of purring like a cat. Graphic Everything look so brown especially the first and third area. Especially the first area because when you exit the town you will see that there is literally a change in the overall saturation of the game. Also I have to state that I used the DX9 backend instead of the DX11 because it still runs badly on my computer merely just to add more reflection and glaring elements.  Gameplay Fun game, you have a hammer from early on that can be used to smash buildings to pieces which is useful since every single building in the game is smashable and since it follows the laws of physics it is completely pointless to destroy the top part of the building since destroying the bottom part will quickly bring it down.Why destroying building you ask? For money to get salvages duh. Salvages used to upgrade the Main Character from a big man with a hammer to a big man with a hammer and 20 kilos of metal strapped to him with a full blow rocket launcher on his back and an exotic martian weapon by his side. The main game of RF:G has you filling a meter and emptying out a meter. The filling one is the morale meter where killing military unit quickly, destroying propaganda and helping out the rebel will fill it. This serves mainly to get more money when doing story mission and for receiving backup which you will seriously need later on. At maximum rate you will get 4 people fighting by your side.The other meter is military control meter where you need to make it zero to unlock story mission and I can't confirm if making zero affects the military hardware they throw at you. Maybe not because I still get tanks and humvee trying to ram me even when the bar is full. You make it go down by destroying military stuff.There are side activities that helps you with lowering those bar as well and they are generally pretty fun mayhem filled things to do that ranges from assaulting base, drive by mission and explosive mission. Generally fun enough. Good thing the story mission is as good as the side mission! Because the story is weak.EDIT: Forgot VehicleVehicle are so tough even your basic buggy can break through concrete wall, lets not even talk about the APC that can smash straight through a building clean. Although they do handle terribly and tend to float all over the place if you hit a bump they're good enough I guess. Also you can change the orientation of your vehicle while in midair so pretty much you can with a bit of practice land perfectly fine on the ground.And that's pretty much for the gameplay, there's stuff to collect, people to rescue and the usual fanfare of open world stuff although some upgrades are evil enough locked behind doing side missions! So go complete them otherwise you won't get some of the gear. SPECIAL SECTION  THE STORY! Pretty much does not suck but is jarring as hell. You see character usually make one appearances then were gone just like that.  Conclusion Yeah it's a fun game where you really are being a Guerrilla Fighter against a military forces. And you do get a lot of toys to play with. Well destroying building never gets old I guess but the story really rubs me the wrong way. Anyways lets wrap this up. RF:G a fun game from a publisher that is legendary in the industries but is no more. Buy this game now that it has steam support. TipsLate game weapons are game breaking,Always be on the run.Just climb on top of that humvee and smash his face in with the hammer. No need to waste ammo shooting the gunner.Always when faced with demolition mission or assault mission use APC to smash through building, Usually they can go right through it.Scoring Methology [Courtesy of Meat King]:-	S-Rank: excellent-	A-Rank: very good-	B-Rank: solid-	C-Rank: satisfactory-	D-Rank: inferiorVerdict: A-Rank Check out the Original Network Groups. 												A pretty good sandbox game, with a mediocre The-Moon-Is-A-Harsh-Mistress-esque story. The really interesting thing about this game is that you are essentially a terrorist fighting the powers that be: the EDF. I, at least, would constantly go around with bombs strapped to my vehicle with a specific target in mind. Success wasn't surviving the attack; it was destroying the target. Even on medium difficulty, when the EDF came in force, it is very hard to survive long. I would have liked this game to be a conversation on terrorism and guerrilla warfare for a good, but extreme, cause. The ambivalence of destroying a civilian structure that probably-- but not certainly-- was a base of operations for the enemy would have been wonderful, and would have made this into a great game. Instead it is a ham-fisted, "the EDF are killing innocent civilians, they are evil tyrants, you must stop them" kind of a deal.Anyway, this open-world, physics-based third person shooter is a fun diversion and it's worth the twenty dollars they're asking. And, yes, seeing that building stand for a split second after most of its supports have been destroyed, then seeing crumble absolutely is one of the most satisfying experiences in video games.

												8/10Overview: 3rd Person Open World The Good:+ Technically the game holds up extremely well, graphics still look nice and the game runs very smoothly despite all the destruction and chaos happening. + The open world of Mars is split into different sectors. Each sector has its own unique setting and look to it. The developers made good use of color hues to really differentiate the different areas. + The sense of destruction in the game is some of the best I've seen in a game to date with very few games matching it. Just about everything that is seen in the game can be destroyed with your sledgehammer, blown up with explosive or shot with rockets. Seeing large buildings crumbling down with debris flying everywhere is very satisfying. + Variety of weapons that fit your play style + Side missions are varied and provide a nice change of pace from the main game. 2 of the main side missions is destruction and transportation. In destruction you have to destroy a building given limited weapons and time. In transportation you have to drive a vehicle to a destination within a time limit.  + As you destroy enemy buildings and complete side/main missions you raise morale allowing more AI to fight alongside with you and gain more ammo from crates. Although it doesn't make the biggest difference in the world it is a nice system given the context of the story. + The game comes with bonus single player DLC which extends the game + In addition to single player, Wrecking Crew mode allows you to play a different levels with a variety of different options either by yourself or with others to try and get a high score. A fun, optional mode that extends your playtime. + Removed games for windows liveThe Average:I found the main missions to be pretty average. Most main missions have you going to a certain location and blowing everything up. I would have liked to see more variety among them.  Because of the lack of variety in main missions, sometimes the game can feel a bit repetitive. The Bad: - Like past Red Faction games the story and characters are forgettable and one dimensional. The story serves as an excuse to blow things up and nothing more. A lot of wasted potential here which is sad given some of the cool locations.  - I hear multiplayer is fun, too bad the community is gone. Conclusion:This is a good mindless fun game that reminded me of Just Cause 2. You go around blowing things up and watch the destruction unfold as you fight wave of enemies attacking you. I am fairly new to this series only having beaten the other two games a few months ago. This is a very interesting series. Red Faction started out as a linear first person shooter, then it became a level based shooter with bosses and then it became a third person open world game. If you love blowing things up then look no further than this game.

												Sure, RFG has been rightly criticised for its boring characters and non-existent storyline, but I feel that people who over-emphasise those shortcomings are rather missing the point.Mechanically, I believe this is one of the greatest games of all time, not just for its destruction engine, which was far ahead of its time, and remains unmatched by anything made since, but also for the way it blends seamlessly into its brilliant combat, and the quality of that combat itself. I've spent hundreds of hours raiding bases in RFG's massive and colourful sandbox world, getting into raging firefights against waves upon waves of troops, tanks and airships, with buildings crashing down as they're hammered by cannon shells and explosive charges, and plowed into by out of control vehicles. The shooting alone is excellent. They've nailed the sense of feedback you get from firing your weapons so that every kill feels inordinately satisfying, more so than in anything else I've ever played. The high quality sound effects and music only complement the effect. You can complain about the story, but I've been playing this for years and never even bothered finishing the main missions. The moment to moment sandbox gameplay is just that good.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												A technical masterpiece with few equals. Red Faction: Guerrilla accomplishes something very few games have ever tried, much less achieved with real success; dynamic destruction with full physics and few - if any - slowdowns accompanying them. While the game is not perfect and even its destruction system can be finicky at times, Guerrilla is a game that I wish had inspired other developers to follow suit.The centerpiece of the experience is the Geo-Mod component of the game that handles dynamic building destruction. From my experience, little comes close to the level of optimization, stability, and overall fidelity that Geo-Mod enables for Red Faction. Practically every building in the game can be demolished in a maddening variety of ways. Strategically knock out primary supports and let the roof cave in, demolish a wall and watch the building topple sideways, or just ram a tank or a few demolitions charges in the front door and let the chaos unfold. Even with hundreds of individual pieces of a structure smashing to the ground and causing even more death or destruction in their descent, the game runs butter-smooth in all but the most catastrophic of collapses.It isn't just Geo-Mod alone that makes the building destruction fantastic, but how the game is set up. From the beginning, Guerrilla understands that demolishing buildings is a core element of the game and incorporates it into everything from sandbox shootouts to evasion missions. Stuck in a corner with bad cover or no ammo? Whip out your sledgehammer and knock a hole in the wall that's got you trapped. Taking fire from a difficult target on a balcony? Chuck a demo charge onto the bottom and bring the floor out from underneath him. Horde of APCs charging over a bridge? Blast a hole in their path and watch them tear apart the bridge's supports on the way down.Unfortunately, all games pay for quality in some area or another. Guerrilla suffers in several. While its shortcomings rarely fall below a professional grade of quality, Guerrilla struggles notably in its writing and offers a fairly light, two-dimensional plot with an antagonist that's almost on par with zombies in lack of characterization and absurdity. Characters on both sides of the firing line aren't developed beyond their basic introductions and the conclusion of the story itself is predictable, at best. The game's wonderful soundtrack almost feels like wasted potential as a result.Combat, graphics, and post-story sandbox activities are smaller failings, but are thankfully not quite as mediocre as the game's story. Gunfighting suffers from enemies lacking satisfying hit feedback and a reliance on weight of numbers and spongy health instead of engaging or varied behavior. The player's arsenal likewise suffers from severe maximum ammunition limits, forcing many weapon switches or battlefield pick-ups to stay competitive. Interplay with the game's destructive environment, good player mobility, and a wealth of available weapons shore up the otherwise forgettable combat, but only enough to keep it from being a chore.Graphically, the game isn't quite up to snuff, but this is understandable given its sandbox nature and physics-heavy environment. Textures are low resolution, models often lack in style or quality, and animations are mixed bag of stiff movement "compensated" by high playback speed. Lighting is often strange inside buildings and the game's low texture resolution is regularly given its own "compensation" with aggressive tiling where applicable. Fortunately, the Geo-Mod system is again of note; its effects, sounds, and behavior make for a stunning experience watching buildings collapse.Overall, while not as well-rounded as it could have been, Guerrilla is an applaudable, enjoyable game that baffles me for all the right reasons; why has no one followed it up, copied it, or took after its lead with its sandbox destruction? Why does a 2009 game have better physics than many games that came much later afterwards? How the Hell does this thing run so smoothly? Finally, why haven't you bought this game yet?

content:
Posted: January 30
												I used to play Jenga as a child, but not in a way one would expect. Sure I would construct precariously high towers, but my aim wasn’t to preserve their structural integrity. I wanted to find interesting ways to topple them, to observe the blocks collapsing inward gradually or being popped outward at speed. That same curiosity surrounding the observation of demolition is precisely what developer Volition channeled into Red Faction: Guerilla. This brilliant infusion elevates an otherwise typical action experience into something memorable.Red Faction Guerilla is set on the planet Mars in the year 2125, and follows the rebellion of a mining colony against the authoritarian regime of an organization known as the Earth Defense Force (or EDF). At the center of the conflict is Alec Mason, an Earthling who has made the journey to Mars seeking an honest job with his brother Dan. Unfortunately, Dan outs himself as an ally of the Red Faction resistance and brings down the full fury of the EDF upon them both. When Dan is gunned down in front of Alec, he begrudgingly joins the cause to put an end to EDF tyranny.Being so straightforward, the plot serves as a loose justification for wantonly blowing things up. There is essentially no character development, with Mason never evolving into anything more than a reluctant jerk. This despite the fact over the course of 20 missions I razed dozens of oppressive EDF structures, murdered hundreds of their troops, and even forged an alliance with a clan of barbarous tribals. It is also heavily implied that Mason has feelings for a member of the Red Faction, yet can’t even commit to her. For the 12 hours it took me to finish the story, Mason was smothered by dialog from jarheads preaching the high-minded notions of a free society, but refused to adopt any of them. I now question why the developer bothered hiring the talented Troy Baker to voice such an unlikeable character in needless cutscenes.Honestly, I would recommend skipping the narrative sequences, as the gameplay more effectively reinforces that the player is an outmatched revolutionary. The game begins in a remote corner of a considerably large open world, only arming the player with some demolition charges and a sledgehammer. In order to unlock missions, you have to destroy valuable EDF property in the region and decrease the strength of their occupation. I learned quite quickly that using hit-and-run tactics was optimal, as a Grand Theft Auto style policing system punishes troublesome players for lingering in an area. As I gradually outfitted Mason with better weapons and upgrades, I found I could dwell progressively longer in locations where EDF forces would have previously crushed me with ease.As I liberated each sector of Mars, the sense of empowerment became more pronounced and satisfying. I eventually moved from destroying inconsequential EDF roadblocks, to leveling entire military bases. My arsenal grew from construction tools to a collection of comedically exaggerated weapons of mass destruction, akin to the inventory of Ratchet and Clank. The increasingly involved story missions became opportunities to compose my own symphony of pandemonium. I no longer had to personally wreck every wall with my sledgehammer, I could use nanomachines to literally eat support beams or wipe out half a building with a thermobaric rocket and let gravity do the rest. Physics became a toy to me, something to experiment with and exploit for my amusement. From the first minute to the last, I never tired of listening to concrete shatter from concussive force or metal beams buckling under topheavy weight.Even the multiplayer leverages these primal delights to spruce up the typical suite of online modes. I regularly exploited the fragility of structures to improvise cover, generate new avenues of movement, and even set deadly traps. Following conventional map routes made me an easy target, while busting through barricades at weird angles often threw my opponents off guard. At times I found it more entertaining to be a human bulldozer than actually participate in the arena shooting. I can more clearly recall instances of disintegrating the ground around an opponent's feet, sending them plummeting to their death, then I can freak headshots. These atypical options motivated my addictive pursuit of chaotic ingenuity, encouraging me to play longer and return sooner.Unfortunately the community is no longer very active, regardless of one million users owning Red Faction Guerilla on Steam. I had to browse the forums and add a dozen strangers to my friends list before I could start lobbies with any consistency. More often than not, I was locked out of certain games types due to our group not meeting the minimum number of participants. While I personally felt the effort to get games going paid off, I would neither expect nor recommend an average consumer do that. If substantial multiplayer components are a factor in your purchasing decisions, looking elsewhere would be more fruitful.This game is also not a graphics benchmark, it is not made to impress computer hardware enthusiasts. The most taxing element of the engine is the proprietary physics tied to rendering chunks of debris as objects are damaged. Large quantities of rubble remain after buildings are dismantled, so areas dense with structures will put a strain on any CPU. Nothing will challenge even the most modest GPU, as the textures and relative draw distance compare to a PlayStation 2 release. However, it is worth noting that since the Red Faction IP was acquired by Nordic Games in 2013,  their programmers put in work to upgrade Red Faction Guerilla to the DirectX 11 API. The update added the ability to toggle appreciable visual effects like ambient occlusion, sun shafts, depth of field, and multisample antialiasing. While these options are fairly standard in software dating back to the DirectX 9 era, legacy support is nonetheless laudable.Ultimately, the adoration of Red Faction Guerilla’s inventive gameplay is why developers and devotees alike support the product at all. It could have been a critical darling if the writers had bothered to flesh out the template characters and scenario. The visual fidelity was also arguably lacking, where even the application of slightly more sophisticated bump mapping or tessellation would have allowed Red Faction Guerilla to age gracefully. As it stands, the game is a cult classic propped up on a foundation of outstanding interactive destruction.---My Set-Up:Hardware - Intel i7 6700k at 4.0 GHZ, 2-Way Nvidia GTX 1070 SLI, 16GBs of 3200mhz clocked RAM, Samsung 950 Pro 512GB NVMe SSD, Windows 10 Pro.Software Settings - 2560 x 1440 resolution, Character FOV 60, 2 Times MSAA, Particle Detail High, Shadow Detail High, Motion Blur Off, Ambient Occlusion Off, Depth of Field Off.Extra Enhancements - 60 FPS cap applied through RivaTuner to ensure locked performance, 16 times anisotropic filtering applied through Nvidia Control Panel, ReShade 3.0 used to inject SMAA and sharpen the image.Notes - Due to the lack of players in the multiplayer community, I resorted to using the Steam Achievement Manager to unlock the following achievements: Experimenter, Detective, Mad Genius, Courier of Pain, Topher Would be Proud, War Veteran, and A Winner is You. I also had to use SAM to unlock an achievement called Revolutionary, as a glitch was occurring that prevented the final side mission I needed to complete from triggering. Had I pursued all of these items as intended, my game time would have been pushed well over one hundred hours. Tens of hours would have been unnecessarily spent waiting in the open world or in multiplayer lobbies.

Posted: March 14, 2015
												Red Faction Guerrilla Steam Edition is a one of a kind Military based shooter. I normally am not one that always plays shooters constantly so this game gave me a change of pace with a great level of difficulty from the very start.  The whole purpose of the game is to try to take over control points to stop this evil organization that has killed many people. In order to take control of these sections of the game you will have to bring down small and then large heavily fortified buildings.    There is little to hardly no cover system so often you may need  to shoot small packs of enemies and then retreat for a bit to get your health meter back up which automatically regenerates and then head right back over that way to finish your mission.  There is a wide variety between the tpes of vehicles you can hop in to remain safe from the opposing faction. The first consists of your normal vehicles you can only drive and have no weapon attachments. You can generally hop in any vehicle even if a civilian or the military organization your taking down is in it. Sometimes this will require you to shoot  them off the turrent based military vehicles so then you can invade control points easier.     In my own opinion wrecking crew mode is the greatest feature of all because it has no story and you just follow short  objectives like blowing up barrels to demolish buildings, using walkers to just obliterate everything standing in your way in what is known as Total chaos mode which is just a free-for-all destroy type of mode within wrecking crew.     My favorite part about this game is the use of Walkers to demolish control points if you are lucky enough to find one. There are usually a few different types but only one that has missles which is something similar to something that would be seen in a Armored core game or even generally comparable to a Star Wars AT-AT walker though smaller.I'll give this game a solid 8.5/10.  I highly recommend you check it out. It is made by THQ which was a company that went bankrupt eventually after having games only targeting family friendly kids games, movies games and then they created fully Muture games which was primarily targeted towards adults though that did not help their downfall as a company.All in all the destructible environments reminded me of some videos I have seen where people play the Battlefield Shooter series.

												Imagine. Grand Theft Auto. Destructable Environments. Free Roam. Future Setting. Now imagine all these things coming together in a collage of a good game. This game has all the things needed on the checklist to be a good game, but it lacks in story and total free roam control. You're not some caution-to-the-wind, I-do-what-I-want protagonist who lives his life by crashing cars and doing drugs. You have a good-Karma kind of sense, and the game punishes you for doing things wrong to any innocent people. Now, as this makes driving lackluster, it makes combat more fun. Because you're rewarded for destruction and murder of enemies of the Red Faction. The game is fun and not too dry for something made a short while ago. It provides many fun times and good laughs and if you're into Xbox gamerscore, this game will sync with your achievements. I'd recommend it, but at 20 dollars, it's kind of a run-of-the-mill game that will be amusing for a good while.

Posted: May 17, 2016
Red Faction Guerilla Steam Edition is a great open-world game that excels at destruction.You play as Alec Mason, an Earth-born miner that comes to Mars looking for a job. Soon after your arrival, you get involved in a guerilla war against the oppressing force - Earth Defense Force. Your mission is to weaken EDF's control over different regions by destroying key buildings and completing optional tasks. Once you lower the control over a region, 3-4 story missions unlock for every region, so there is a little grinding involved for progression. Bring EDF's control to 0 in a region and you can take it over.The gameplay is focused on destruction, as it should be because this game uses a very nice physics engine. There are a lot of tools to blow things up: items in the environment, mines, placeable detonators, rocket launcher, etc. You even get rewarded with scrap (game currency) for bringing down structures and making stuff go boom. There are also regular guns such as a pistol and assault riffle, but these are less fun to use. Later in the game you will have access to better guns and gadgets, but you will need a big amount of scrap if you want to unlock everything. My favourite combination was sniping with the nano-rifle from mid-air (using jetpack).  I didn't play Red Faction Guerilla in its original itteration, but from the information available it looks like the developers cared enough for the game to improve a lot and re-release it in a better state. If you like open-world games such as Saints Row, Just Cause or Max Mad then it is a must-play. If not, I would still recommend to give this one a try. You will have a blast, I promise.

Posted: February 21
												I tend to call this game the last great destructible scenery game. Red faction since its inception has given players enormous freedom in blowing open walls to make new paths, blowing up bridges to drop things, etc. Red factio Guerrilla is the pinnacle of this system, with a truly beastly amount of freedom to destroy. Car bombing a building into a tiny pile of rubble is totally possible. The fact that the game has this system but does not force you to use it means that players can just as easily go in tactically on a mission despite all the explosive possibilities. You can blow the entire block up to kill a target, or blow a hole in the roof and blast him. Vehicles are not left out of this and can be used to destroy things just as easily as a det charge. In terms of story, it really is not bad at all, nothing groundbreaking, but the fact it ties into the old games and still stands out with cool themes of its own (Such as the awesomely dressed raider faction) makes it a pleasure to find in a game that could easily have shipped with a cookie cutter story. The weapon selection is extravagant and awesome, with precision deconstruction weapons like the nano rifle, and massive ordinance like the thermobaric rocket that can level blocks. While the game in large part is totally badass, there are some pitfalls. The inability to redo main missions is bad to find in an open world game, though theres alot of side missions that can be replayed, that does not excuse the inability to redo missions. Along the same lines, if you destroy many landmarks, those landmarks do not come back, ever. Blow up the biggest coolest bridge in the game and thats it, never again. Many buildings do respawn, especially ones used in side missions, but the many that do not are a sad one time but of fun that will never be again. So overall, red faction guerrilla is a game with a fantastic destruction system, above any other game to come out before or since. Blow everything up, deconstruct your enemies bunkers, bridges, and tanks. Sneak in, blow your way out. use vehicles as disguises, wrecking balls, or escape methods. Work with the reistance. This game is a great example of an open world game made right, but with the downfalls of diminished replayability due to being unable to replay missions or regenerate the environment.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
												The environmental damage takes centre stage in this game, buildings can be torn down piece by piece, they have weaknesses to their architectural structure, and other surfaces can be smashed and mutilated. The environment always feels alive, the wind blows dust across your path and howls gently, the EDF are always carrying out patrol routes and intimidating civilians, then we have the safe houses where your fellow faction members are deep in conversation and planning their next moves. There are various sectors to explore, each with their own distinct look and feel. You will start your journey in a quieter and more open desert area, then move to a rocky wasteland, and venture across more urban and densely populated areas.Environmental design has also been taken into consideration, there are some vast open areas but all of the sectors are connected well and just as easy to navigate. In-game character models are well crafted and animations perform competently as the gameplay pushes the boundaries of pure carnage. The soundtrack deserves praise as it matches the ambient nature of Mars. The story missions revolve around helping the Red Faction overthrow the EDF and liberate each sector; once a sector is free of EDF control then no enemy forces will bother you in that zone. A lot of the time you are outnumbered and it isn't always easy to take out specific targets. The A.l. for your guerrilla allies can be really clumsy at times, some missions require you to free captured guerrilla fighters and get them to safety. For some reason, sometimes they don’t wish to get in a getaway car with you and end up fending off enemy forces at their own demise. Perhaps it would have helped having some greater control over freedom fighters.

content:
Posted: March 7
												Let me just state this upfront: Red Faction Guerilla is a great deal of fun most of the time.  This should likely come as no surprise to anyone familiar with the developer’s (Volition) most famous (and ridiculously fun and absurd) series, Saints Row.  That being said, Guerilla is far from a perfect game and definitely shows its age in some respects.  But first, the positives.  Like I said before, there is a lot of fun to be had in Guerilla and this is due in large part to the Geo-Mod system the game employs which essentially allows for you tear down damn near every structure in the game, brick by brick.  There’s an extremely visceral amount of fun to be had simply roaming around the Martian landscape plowing through buildings or bashing away at a building with your trusty sledgehammer before hearing that telltale creak that signifies a building is about to come crashing down all around you and scrambling to get out of the way of the debris.  Additionally, the system can even take on a bit of a puzzle like aspect as you try to find the most efficient manner of bringing a building down with your remote charges or rocket launcher.  From a technical aspect, the game is also well optimized for most any PC.  I tested the game on a mid-range laptop (8 GB RAM, i5 processor, and integrated graphics card) and it ran with very few problems (there were a few frame rate hiccups here and there when the destruction started to get really crazy but even still it was absolutely playable) on low to medium settings.  When I moved over to my desktop though (i7, 16 GB RAM, with a GeForce GT 730) I was able to get silky smooth performance at higher settings.  For what it’s worth, I’ve also played Guerilla on my 360 and while performance there was closer to what I saw on my laptop, I would still recommend it on that system to anyone who asked.Unfortunately, a lot of what’s surrounding the actual gameplay in Guerilla leaves a fair bit to be desired.  The story of the game is utterly forgettable and extremely self-serious which is quite disappointing, especially in light of what Volition would ultimately go on to do in the Saints Row series.  I honestly couldn’t tell you the name of more than two or three characters in Guerilla and to say that the characters who are present in the game lack definition would be putting things lightly.  The Witcher 3 this game is not but then again not every game has to be. What’s a bigger issue though, is that the game is unfortunately afflicted with an issue present in a lot of open world games in that there simply isn’t a lot there to make the world feel alive.  Much of the time you’ll simply be driving between the different “Guerilla Actions” (essentially side quests and events) or EDF (the game’s primary villain) bases looking for more targets to destroy with little points of interest in between.  Furthermore, I found the actual combat present in the game to be frustrating at times as there’s a surprisingly low ammo ceiling for the weapons you can carry and Alec Mason (the game’s protagonist) proved to be somewhat fragile in terms of survivability.  There is a cover system present in the game, but it’s laughably simple at best and actually detrimental to your play at worst as you can pretty easily get stuck to walls and find yourself swarmed with EDF goons in pretty short order.  I typically found it a lot easier to instead just get in whatever vehicle I could find and ram through as many enemies as I could before actually getting out and engaging in a direct fire fight.That being said though, I would still recommend this game purely based on the amount of fun there is to be had with the destructibility of the environment.  Just know before going in that there are some gameplay frustrations that you’ll have to push through and that there really isn’t anything waiting for you at the end in terms of a satisfying narrative. Guerilla is one of those game’s you should play for exactly as long as you’re still having fun blowing stuff up and then feeling fine dropping once that loses its luster.

												Red Faction Guerrilla is now free of GFWL! If sandbox style, open world play is your thing, I thoroughly recommend Red Faction Guerrilla. While it's getting a bit long in the tooth these days, both visually and mechanically, it's still a great game for tooling about and destroying things.While this is one of my favourite sandbox games, my recommendation comes with a cople of caveats; mission checkpointing can be a little harsh at times, and the game really is mostly about choosing your own way of doing the missions you're given. There is a story, and there are many, many missions. But the true joy is in deciding how to approach a given challenge with all the tools the game provides, especially in terms of destructibility. And when you screw up, you're sent back to the beginning of a mission, so repetition is virtually inevitable. Therefore, if you like your game experiences more towards the curated end of the spectrum, I can't extend this recommendation to you. This is very much a game that lets to find your own fun in a science fiction world, but helps that along by providing tools of sheer destructive joy.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2016
												Red Faction Guerrilla is good for what it is, but it is starting to show its age.The building destruction mechanics are awesome, and there still aren't really any games that compare to how satisfying and detailed the destruction of buildings is. Sadly, the insides of buildings feel very lifeless compared to the sculpted mountains and hills of Mars. Add the fact that you can raze the entire building with a mis-click, it adds to the lifelessness of buildings, and the world feels somewhat better without them. 90% of the buildings don't ever respawn, which means once you enjoy the destruction of everything on Mars once, you won't be able to do it again on the same save file. Also, having good building destruction kind of pales in comparison to the terrain deformation from the original Red Faction, and it is a shame that they couldn't somehow implement that as well.The combat is the usual stale third person shooter type, similar to Watchdogs. The melee with things like hammers is pretty satisfying against enemies, though it is very risky on harder difficulties since enemies will take out half of your health with great accuracy while running up to them. The driving is OK, a little stiff, but solid. Smashing a truck through an outpost is great, and really highlights the great destruction engine.The graphics are fast becoming very dated. The cutscenes look almost like something from a PS2 game, the human models look kind of chunky, like action figures, and I don't know if it's just me but the sound files for voice acting sound really compressed and garbage sounding, as if they were from a game from 2002. Mars looks fine, it looks like Mars.The game is pretty unbalanced on the hard difficulty. Enemies empty magazines into you with very little inaccuracy, and because the health regeneration takes such a long time to begin, the sheer amount of enemies that start chasing you will kill you. The enemies also take a huge amount of damage. It helps make the EDF feel more like armoured bad guys, but it's very annoying using all of your ammo on only 3 normal bad guys, especially when there are 12 more around the corner. The sheer randomness of the physics system also takes part in causing much frustration. Sometimes getting hit in the head with a fallen turbine blade will only give you some damage and won't knock you down. Sometimes a stray hand-railing will knock you down, take out a quarter of your health, and pin you under a nearby walkway making you a sitting duck for enemy soldiers while you wait for the standing up animation to happen. I don't know what a remedy could be for something like this, because it makes sense to die from a bulding landing on your head. But sometimes the physics are just too random.Overall, the game is good. It's just kind of showing it's age with some other problems from the time. If you are in the mood for games like GTA, Watchdogs, or other third-person drivey-shooty games, then this game will fit the bill with some added cathartic destruction.

Even better now that GFWL is dead! Definitely worth playing!

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												Red Faction Guerrilla is an open world sand box game with an interesting narrative and fantastic amounts of playability.Open world games are certainly not my kind of game, however this game excels in the fact there is a linear, developing plot as you progress from story mission to story mission, without this, the game would have been a flop in my honest opinion.The game didn't hook me at first, but the moment they put a gun in my hands, and I was fighting hordes of EDF soldiers, that's when I started to become hooked. The gun play feels refreshing, impactful and enjoyable. That and the fact that it isn't your stereotypical cover shooter... because the cover will just get blown up! It's great that for once, the best way to play is aggressively, it really helps make it refreshing.the game heavily features driving segments, and they aren't F-zero GX quality driving segments either. This would hinder the game, but it actually helps a lot. It gives you time to immerse yourself into the game and the game world. Eventually you do get a fast transport system, which is fantastic, but you still need to drive to your destinations. This combined with the raid missions which have colonists hop in your vehicle, makes the driving all the more pleasant.And on the topic of colonists, this is where the game truly shines. You can sing praises on the destruction physics, but what really makes this game amazing in my eyes, is the Morale and NPC interactions. As you fight the EDF and complete objectives, more and more colonists will fight by your side. One particular cause of this, is the EDF assault missions, where EDF Armoured personal carriers and tanks drive into a colonist base, and you must fight them off. As your Morale increases, more and more of these NPC's fight by your side, it makes the world feel real, and helps really show that the mission your doing actually have weight behind them. The morale goes as far to change the dialog of the NPC's when you walk past them, which is truly the icing on the cake for me.The games plot is nothing to write home about, but the game does a great job immersing yourself in the world at least, thanks to features like the Morale system, as described earlier.  The mission variety also helps a lot in keeping the game interesting. The Jenkins missions are a little bit boring by the end, as its basically a gallery turret segment, and timed driving segments would have been better if the driving itself was more enjoyable, but it is what it is. The two artillery segments towards the end where mediocre at best, but they weren't bad, I'm glad they were included just to spice things up a little right at the end, but I would have preferred to only have had that segment played once, and not twice.However, the expanding diversity of guns and upgrades, and the dynamic, highly entertaining Havok physics engine made this game a stellar experience. A fantastic game, definitely worth the time and effort (and of course the money) to play, you will (probably) not regret it!

content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
												A very fun open world action game. What makes Red Faction: Guerrilla stand out is the destruction physics which are truly awe-inspiring. They are not like what you see in other games, it is much more in depth. Its very satisfying to take a hammer and reduce a building to dust, watch it crumble apart, it never really gets old. The moment I picked up the hammer and break down the first wall in the tutorial was when I knew it was cool.One fun memory I had of this game was when I was inside a building and there was an enemy tank firing at the building and I saw the building I was in crumble around me, the building falling apart in front of your eyes, the walls would get destroyed and troops would start firing on me through them, I rush outside just in time before the building clopses completely. Another time, I had to kill some snipers on the roof, so I used the disintegrate gun to shoot the ceiling of a building and the sniper on top fell through and I hit him with my hammer. It creates a new dimension to sandbox games that you don't see in many other games and has yet to be topped to this day. Every time you pilot a tank and fire missiles into buildings, or a mech suit and rage through buildings, is awesome. Why somebody hasn't taken this technology and applied it to a pure tank or mech game is beyond me, as the missions where you pilot a tank or a mech suit were probably my fondest memories of this game and could have made a great tank or mech game with them.Some missions did not utilize the destruction physics to their fullest potential, such as any of the driving missions which are usually really boring with floaty driving (although given the setting on Mars I suppose it makes sense), however most of them were very good. My favourite side missions were the demolition ones where you level a building or structure using limited supplies, like a puzzle almost, which were fun, and I also really enjoyed the house arrest side missions where you have to rescue fellow resistance fighters because in those missions, you have to actually be careful about which parts of the building you want to destroy as you don't want to level the building with your buddies inside it or you lose, which you don't really need to do in the rest of the game.There were a few design flaws, such as when a fellow guerilla helps you out and gets killed and you support in that area because the AI isn't the greatest. Losing 3 support points every time you die in free roam was annoying too. Plus sometimes buildings would be held up with only one wall and wouldn't fall over, when in real life they would have. I wish this game would have gotten a real sequel that expanded upon the destruction physics and made them even better and more satisfying, it could have even been a more linear game or a level based game like Hitman because most of the actual missions in Guerrilla are quite linear themselves.The focus is on the sandbox fun and the story is a loose framework to hang this on. I recommend skipping the cutscenes because they are pretty boring, plus it was not very clear on who the Maurauders are in the story. All you need to know is that there's an evil totalitarian government and you're out to take them down and get revenge.Music and audio were fine. Multiplayer is pretty dead but I've heard its fun so there might be some steam groups around to play with.Overall, definitely worth playing through, I played it years ago on console and it still holds up today. I played it on Hard this time and the difficulty was still fine, it was fun on Normal too, will play through it on Insane sometime in the future.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												Download size: about 8 GBPlaytime: about 12 hours for single playerThe newly updated Red Faction Guerilla steam edition comes with trading cards and achievements since they migrated away from Games For Windows Live. It also seems to be less buggy, but this may be a coincidence. You don’t need to have played the previous Red Faction games to understand what’s going on, and if you played Red Faction Armageddon, the campaign story isn’t really spoiled for you either. The stories take place with enough time in between for all sorts of things to have happened.You play as Alec Mason, a recent immigrant to Mars planning to live with his brother as a miner (actually a scavenger of salvage). Unfortunately your plans are ruined when you experience the brutality of the EDF (Earth Defense Fleet), the powerful military organization that seems to be in the pocket of all the major corporations keeping the working man down. Alec joins the Red Faction, which is a kind of resistance/terrorist group committed to driving the EDF off of Mars by any means necessary. So now you (as Alec) spend your time blowing things up (and collecting salvage).Red Faction Guerilla is a third person open world game, similar to Grand Theft Auto or the Saints Row games. Since it takes place on Mars, there’s also reduced gravity though you don’t really get to fly around everywhere, even after you get a jet pack. The trademark of all Red Faction games is destructible environments, so like Red Faction Armageddon, you can pretty much destroy any man-made structure in the game, including buildings, bridges, walls, and all the crates the EDF leaves lying around. There are a few things that might give you trouble, for example some buildings have indestructible metal girders as part of the construction, but you can still knock them around and cause the buildings to collapse. It’s probably easiest to just ram your cars into the buildings though. Yes, like Grand Theft Auto and Saints Row, you can hijack all sorts of cars (no aircraft) and drive all over the map. The game world is moderately large and probably would take 15 minutes of straight driving to get across it. You can’t do that though since Mars has mountains and valleys blocking you so you mostly need to follow roads.You can carry up to 4 weapons at a time, but one of them is locked as your trusty sledgehammer, which is decent for destroying buildings. There isn’t too much variety in the projectile weapons, and you’ll probably stick will explosive weapons in order to bring down buildings. Weapons and their upgrades are unlocked in the game by completing side missions or just picking them up from fallen enemies. Once you’ve unlocked the weapon you can restock it from any of your “safe houses” around the map. Money in the game is salvage, which shows up as shiny metal that you can pick up by walking over. Most of your salvage will likely come from completing missions, but a there’s a lot to be gained from the rubble of buildings.Pros:+Wreck buildings in all sorts of ways. Usually the quickest way is using explosive weaponry, which has ammo limitations, so I like to try and crash cars into the buildings whenever possible. Just make sure you have enough room to build up ramming speed (and enough firepower to survive the EDF retaliation).+The game has multi player which I only dabbled in for about an hour. There are actually people still playing but not more than a dozen or so at a time. No co-op campaign play however, which is a shame. There are a lot of multi-player modes, but people only seem to be playing the deathmatch types.Cons-Unfortunately for me, a large number of the game’s Steam achievements are for grinding in multiplayer, and a bunch of the single player achievements require finding ALL of certain types of collectibles. -The game’s side quests become repetitive after a while and by the time you unlock the game’s final area, you probably won’t be doing any of the side quests since you’ll be bored by then. -For an older game, my computer actually heats up when I play for a while. The game uses Havok engine, which seems to appear in a ton of the games I’ve been playing recently, but the game’s graphics aren’t much better than say, Fallout 3.All in all Red Faction Guerilla is a good game worth your weekend to play through. The campaign has its exciting points and it’s fun to go around blowing up buildings. The DLC Demons of the Badlands is included in the Steam edition (I don’t know if the GFWL version had it). The DLC is about 3 hours and includes a few new weapons to play with, as well as a completely useless new kind of collectible (battery packs that don’t do anything). At least in the main game, all the collectibles had some sort of benefit (like give you a little salvage).

Posted: April 7, 2014
												There aren't a lot of games like Red Faction: Guerrilla out there but I've got to say I loved it.The game's emphasis is basically centered around blowing stuff. And carnage. And blowing some more stuff up. I lost count of how many times I just went on rampages throughout the various sectors, trying to destroy key strategic places while having the EDF on my♥♥♥♥♥trying to stop me. The fully destructible environments and buildings just give you such an amazing sense of freedom and endless shortcut potential. Combine that with the possibility of driving overpowered mechs and tanks, and you've got a really fun game to just mess about.It is also open world, so there's plenty of side missions here and there, and unmarked collectibles, but this made me recall the first Assassin's Creed, and not in a good way. See, while there are several types of side missions, every time you visit a new sector, you just end up getting the same side missions anyway. You really just end up feeling like you're doing the same thing over and over again even when you're in a new zone, just like Assassin's Creed. There's a few dynamic ones that pop up when you might just be wandering around, but again, not a lot of variety.I absolutely love Colonial Mars. You don't see it depicted often, and it is that sweet blend of early colonization + open expanses of wilderness. The sectors themselves, of which there are quite a few, do have their own personality and flavor. The whole vibe it gave off really reminded me of driving the Mako in Mass Effect.The plot itself is pretty standard really, usual insurgent rebels fighting evil empire with superior forces. There were a few plot twists here and there but I found most of it, including the story missions, rather underwhelming. Personally though, the freedom fighter premise is something that never really gets old for me, so I did enjoy it nevertheless.All in all though, totally recommend this one. While it may not be thought provoking long after you've beaten it, you will remember the slaughter you've inflicted as your carefully planted bombs collapse that huge apartment block in one go, causing its floors to crash on the enemies' unsuspecting heads as you break a hole in a wall to cut a shortcut and make your escape. Fun stuff.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Red Faction: Guerrilla Steam Edition is an amazing package with the original game and includes all released DLC - including the Demons of the Past campaign and continues to receive updates and support from the developers. Finally, a true Red Faction game that utilizes the Geo-Mod destruction to the fullest potential on all structures (not on terrain like the original game)! Everything is destructible which creates amazing explosions and the desire to blow everything up. The game does a good job requiring the player to destroy buildings and other barriers in order to progress. This is the first game I have ever seen that actually allows you to raze structures to the ground and uses physics for the explosions and for the structural intergrity. It's awesome to see a building stand on one leg for a few seconds before it crumbles to the ground. The story is pretty good and there are a ton of missions available (~100). The optional missions become really repetitive so I stopped after doing about half of them. There are tons of collectibles to find as well, including mining ore locations, finding radio tags and destroying propaganda. Overall, I was able to find all the collectibles, beat the game and the DLC in about 30 hours and when you're blowing stuff up it's a ton of fun! Only negatives I can complain about is the weather/fog is way too thick sometimes impairing the player's vision and the enemy is able to shoot you through it with no issue and near the later half of the game everything feels pretty repetitive driving from point A to point B and doing the same thing over: do the same type of missions to reduce the control of the sector, blow stuff up and then do the story missions to free the sector. If you're looking for a game just to blow stuff up or wanting to try a Red Faction game, then look no further this is the game to get! Lastly, I need to mention the soundtrack in this game is awesome!

Simply going around and demolishing buildings with a sledgehammer for no reason whatever is a blast. The actual missions are good too though. Some of the weapons and gadgets you acquire by the end are very creative and fun to use. For example: the pulse rifle (which makes a return from the original Red Faction) which allows you to see and shoo through walls, a gun that can literally disintegrate matter, and even a jetpack. It's not a flawless game. I have some issues with it. For example, it allows you to carry only four weapons at any one time. Ideally I would've liked to have all my arsenal available at all times for a game like this. Or it could've allowed you to purchase additional slots at least. Instead you have to look for these ammo crates which are scattered around the map. They allow you to switch weapons and refill some of your ammo of which you can't carry all that much. Also, checkpoints are rather sparse. More often than not if you fail a mission you have to start all the way from the beginning of it. Some of the missions include lengthy shootouts or driving sections and it can be frustrating to have to redo the entire thing. It is an older game but is not old enough for it to be an excuse. To be fair, I played on hard so these last issue may not be so pronounced on lower difficulties. In fact, I found it a bit more difficult than I would've liked but I didn't want to change the difficulty midway through the campaign. Not impossible or anything but I died quite a lot in the second half. It's the kind of game in which I just want to feel like a badass and blow♥♥♥♥♥♥up and not worry too much about dying. If I ever replay it I'll play on medium.The driving is fine. Nothing special about it but it works well enough. The variety of vehicles is not too great but they feel distinct from one another. The damage system on them is not very impressive considering what you can do to buildings. Every now and again you can get your hands on a mech (or walker or whatever) and those a lots of fun. Unfortunately, you only seem to be able to get them during specific missions.Graphically, it looks good considering its age. With everything maxed out in 1080p it is still pleasing to the eye. The performance was locked at 60fps 90% of the time but, unfortunately, I got some drops during more intensive scenes. Particularly when you are standing next to a huge collapsing building with lots of particle effects around you. When you walk right through a building with a mech, for instance, it will slow down noticeably. I'm talking low 50's to mid 40's at the worst and only rarely. I have a 1060 6GB and i5-6500 and both of them were running at around 35-40% capacity. It's definitely not my hardware. The game doesn't seem to be able to take advantage of the extra power you throw at it during these more intense moments.Overall, like a said, it's a very good game and I had loads of fun with it. Highly recommended if you like wreaking havoc in open world games. I'm surprise that they haven't made a newer game recently or that anyone hasn't picked up the idea of a huge open world game with destructible environments.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2016
												First of all, I want to say that the destruction in this game is extremely satisfying, just having the ability to bring any building to rubble usually means everything is getting demolished, either with explosives or when they run out, your sledgehammer.But this game really doesn't benefit being an open-world game. Sure, you get to run around playing terrorist on Mars blowing up any building in your path, then having to evade the authorities which is simply achieved by just driving to the closest safehouse. Mostly what happens though is you drive for a few minutes to get to something worth destroying, blow up things until you're out of explosives which then means driving all the way back to the safehouse to restock, and then driving all the way back to something to destroy and repeat which tends towards extremely tedious gameplay, even if the destroying part is incredibly fun.Driving around the world just feels empty (sure, it's Mars) but there is literally nothing worth driving to other than indicators on the map, there's nothing to really discover. No particular area feels like it is fully fleshed out and designed to the level it would have, had it not been open world. These problems aren't unique to Guerrilla as many open world games fail to get this right but it doesn't really try to do anything new in the open-world space either.For me, the game would have been much more enjoyable just dropping you into an area with your goal and blowing your way to it using the fantastic destruction engine rather than the tedium of constantly having to drive get more ammo, or your next mission, killing the flow of the game.

Posted: December 21, 2013
												This game is so good and so cheap, every time it's on sale I buy gift copies for everyone I know. It's also the only game I've happily bought on or near release day at full price for two systems (PS3 and PC), and willingly suffered GFWL for. About 60% of my hours on this game are on PS3 and 39% on a non-steam retail PC copy, so this is probably my most played game ever.If you're looking for story, stealth, or graphical fidelity, you'll probably be left unsatisfied, but this game absolutely nails gameplay, gameplay as metaphor, atmosphere and iconic imagery with a sledgehammer. The sledgehammer is absolutely the icon of this game, you really feel the crushing oppression in a ragged-edge backwater off-world colony in the quiet moments, and like an outgunned, outnumbered maniac at the end of his rope tearing apart a whole army at its foundations in the chaotic ones (even the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ AI contributes to this feeling), and above all, between the bouncy vehicles, tactile destruction, responsive gunplay, hugely varied weapons and swarms of enemies, the gameplay is just flat-out FUN.The multiplayer is endless fun when you can actually get a game, which is sadly very hard to do these days, but if you try on Wednesdays and Sundays and suffer GFWL, you can usually get a couple of rounds in.Can't recommend enough.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2014
												I just now got this game on Steam, having some 100 hours on my hard copy, but nonetheless it is an amazing game. It's destruction engine is still all but unmatched, and the "insane" difficulty level gives anyone a huge challenge to raid enemy fortifications with the utmost stealth (or I guarantee you will die). It has plenty of "standard" (i.e: Pistol, Assault Rifle, Shotgun, etc) weapons, as well as end-game toys to just screw around with. It's also good to occasionally gaze up into the Martian sky...seeing the beautifully rendered Heavens above, with a comet streaking past every so often.Let me talk for a minute about the destruction engine: off the top of my head, there are 2 things that cannot be destroyed in this game: the terrain and those big♥♥♥♥♥towers in the games last stage. Every other building, however, you can destroy essentially brick by brick, with any non-energy weapon (even your fist). The engine also understands that if you take out critical points of a structure, it will fall much easier than just randomly blowing the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of it.The EDF in this game are also very realistic (on the highest difficulty at least, I haven't played medium or easy in such a long time), as in they behave like police. If you commit a felony and they see you, every one of them in close proximity will fire warning shots and try to "capture" you. If you start killing them, they send in reinforcements. If you're just being a big enough♥♥♥♥♥♥about killing them, they send in tanks and even ♥♥♥♥ing gunships (yes, they have an airforce). If you try to hide from them, they search the area for quite a long time, unlike in other games where once you leave their sight you're free to do whatever.However, I'd like to talk for a moment about the hilarity of their pilots and drivers. The EDF will often flip their cars and crash into each other or even drive off a damn cliff when they're pursuing you, and they will often just fly their gunships into tall buildings, mountains, or even each other. It's really ♥♥♥♥ing hilarious and I'd say buy this game just to♥♥♥♥♥♥off the EDF.But aside from that, I 100% recommend this game. Buy it and play it, then let your kids play it, and let their kids play it. This game is really ♥♥♥♥ing underrated. Spread the word of how amazing this game is (but not the GFWL part. That part sucks).

I'd say a medium sized chunk of the game is a grind, but it's got it's fun moments with the sheer destruction chaos.   Last level was a bit confusing as I often got to the end, but got stuck inside the final 'thingee" somehow.  Maybe it was a controller issue.  Got this in a bundle and don't regret it at all.  Don't expect much story line, though.
