content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Red Faction: Guerrilla is a somewhat open-world FPS with RPG elements. While you have freedom to move about, you cannot access the next area until you've completed certain objectives. Overall, the graphics are great, and the game-play, handling and general game progression is good. You play a character who leads a rebellion, but the planets governing body is too large and your resources are too little. The only way to put a dent in their regime, is to use guerrilla tactics. You infiltrate an area, do as much damage as you can, and then retreat to either another location, or come back to the same place, but only once the guards disperse. You cannot take on a whole encampment or patrol detachment and stay fighting for prolonged periods of time, so for all the fan-boys who like to rampage unchecked, this is not the game for you. If you enjoy a mix of stealth, strategy and abrupt yet massive destruction and carnage with brief pauses in between for tactics, then you'll love this game. I thoroughly enjoyed it. Having 30 years of video game experience under my belt, I can tell you with an extreme level of certainty, this game is unique and enjoyable.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												EDIT: Recent update fixes most problems, definitely worth playing the game now.OK, kids gather round - it's time for a story. You'll like this story. I call it 'XenoPB's Wonderful Adventure with RF:G and GFWL.' It's an emotional story filled with ups and downs that teaches us that in life, ultimately the only one that wins is Gaben.XenoPB liked RF:G, in fact back when he played it on the PS3 he would have been tempted to list it in his top 10 favourite games. Xeno was really looking forward to getting the game on PC and being able to play at 1080p and 60fps. But alas there was one who stood in his path, one who would force Xeno to write an angry and negative review, one who went by the name of 'GFWL.' The young lad, Xeno knew of GFWL, but was confident that he could triumph such a foe, so with this confidence he had in himself, he decided it was an excellent idea to purchase RF:G when Steam tempted him with an seductive 90% off sale. RF:G had now been added to Xeno's Steam Library. It looked happy and at home, nestled between Psychonauts and Red Orchestra 2  as it downloaded. After a short while, the download finished and RF:G quickly installed. RF:G booted up; the THQ logo appeared on screen, it soon faded away and was replaced my some more logos. The logos were closely followed by a loading screen and then, at long last, the main menu. Out of habit, Xeno immediately sped in the direction of the options menu and adjusted it to his needs. It was at this point his enthusiasm began to fade away. Xeno knew that in order to save his game, he would be required to log into GFWL. "No problem," he thought, confidently as he clicked on the large icon in the bottom left corner saying 'LIVE.' The 'LIVE' icon transported Xeno to what is commonly referred to as the 'GFWL login screen.' He thought back to GTA4 and how this same login screen had appeared then. It was at this point that Xeno entered his login details, while grunting in disgust at the very sight of GFWL. It worked; Xeno logged into GFWL. Now another screen had appeared. GFWL was asking for a product key for RF:G. With a quick tap of shift and tab, Xeno located his product key and entered it into the space allocated.The end was in sight. Xeno gave a sigh of relief, confident that soon he would be able to play RF:G and save his progress after doing so. But it appeared that he was not destined to do so. GFWL looked in Xeno's direction and with an insultingly voiced "nope," GFWL displayed a third message to him: "Your Windows Live ID is locked. To check your Windows Live ID, go to http://account.live.com." Xeno collapsed to the floor, clutching his chest and gasping for breath. "No," he repeated, each one louder and angrier than the last. Slowly rising into his chair, determined to play RF:G, Xeno closed the game down and visited the accursed, 'http://account.live.com'.http://account.live.com looked at Xeno with a hostile gaze, one that said "You will not leave here alive." He was told to attempt to log in to GFWL. Xeno did as http://account.live.com commanded, he even typed out the distorted letters he saw in a small box, proving that he was in fact, a real person. http://account.live.com informed Xeno that he had entered the incorrect login details. Xeno protested. He was certain he was correct, he would bet anything on it! He was going to prove http://account.live.com wrong! Xeno entered the login details and typed out the letters a few times, each time being told he was incorrect. Too blinded by ignorance to simply change his password or something, Xeno decided that the best course of action in this case was to make a second account for GFWL, so that next time he would know the correct login details and be able to prove http://account.live.com wrong. It took a few minutes for Xeno to make his new account. Now was the time to boot up RF:G for a second time and show GFWL who the true champion will be in the end. But once again, Xeno could not help but feel he was not destined to play RF:G. The THQ logo appeared on the monitor, RF:G was booting up. But there was a problem. THQ wasn't fading away like it usually did, it just stayed there, motionless. The game had crashed. After his first failed attempt, numerous times, Xeno attempted to launch RF:G again, but it crashed each time. His m8, bLuE, taunted him from their Steam Chat, finding Xeno's pain amusing somehow. After 15 or so attempts to launch the game without ever attempting to search online for a solution, due to Xeno being thick, RF:G finally caved in and allowed passage to the main menu. The 'LIVE' icon was still in the bottom left corner. It got clicked. The GFWL login screen appeared once again. Now an mlg pro at logging in to things, Xeno entered his login details and was once again asked for his product key. Xeno entered the product key a second time.  A different message appeared this time. It told Xeno that the product key he entered was already locked to his first GFWL account. Promptly, Xeno opened the Steam Chat with bLuE and typed "Fudge this."After being knocked down numerous times by his foe, Xeno accepted GFWL's terms and agreed to play RF:G in offline mode, without save files. The opening cutscene began to play, but armed with the knowledge from his first playthrough on console that the story was ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ terrible, Xeno wisely chose to skip it. Now he was in the game, at long last. Xeno was standing on a hill with his in-game brother and looking down on some sort of enclosed area. The textures on some objects were flickering violently, Xeno tried to ignore it, he wouldn't let such an issue stop him from destroying colossal structures with his magical wonder hammer. With a firm press of 'W,' Xeno instructed his character to walk down the hill, but even with GFWL conquered, he was not destined to play RF:G. Before the bottom of the hill was reached, RF:G crashed again.Xeno's face was emotionless. His soul had been crushed. Out of only raw instinct, he opened up his Steam Chat with bLuE and once again proclaimed: "Fudge this."The End

 Red Faction Guerrilla Review === Rating: 7.0 / 10 - An average open world TPS / Action game ===Disclaimer:I have completed this game before on a not steam version, then got on Steam with some bundle and played it again with some modding involved. I did not complete the main campaign on this version because the custom modding i made broke a main quest, but i completed the game already. Just to inform you guys this is a proper review like always.=== Pros & Cons  + Pros + + Everything can be destroyed, with accurate physics simulation, one of the best destructibilities ever seen in gaming even in 2016+ Fun gameplay+ Many upgrades to unlock + Many side quests, albeit repetitive in some cases, some others are very varied and challenging, depends on the type + Colonial mars is an original and interesting setting+ Good AI of enemies and allies+ Good variety of weapons and gadgets - Cons - - Short. On max difficulty, doing all the side missions and main quest, top longevity is 16 hours- Unrealistic damage on people. You can fall down a mountain by rolling all the way down and be fine or with some minor damage afterwards. Same for all characters.- Graphics quality, especially on textures, shaders and models, is pretty bad even for the year this title came out.- Storyline and main characters are stereotyped and anonymous, they mostly will not involve the player=== Conclusions Mostly, RFG is good just for its gameplay based on awesome destruction. All other aspects are much sub-par in terms of quality, but the gameplay is the real deal and is realized perfectly.If you do not care about some pretty bad graphics, story, characters and some locations but just care about having fun and good gameplay, this is for you.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												Smash buildings and hit people in the face with a sledgehammer.  Whats not to like.On a more serious note the damage model makes the game.  There's a few issues with the graphics under DX10 but these can be fixed by running in DX9 mode.   There's a few threads on how to fix DX10, but none worked for me with the remaining suggestions covering all sorts of things with the potential to break your system.  TBH not worth the effort and DX9 mode only means a few extra graphical effects are missing, nothing major.  The selection of weapons in the game complement the smash-it-up feel and the AI's acceptable.  Played through till the end and enjoyed the lot.  One thing to note a lot of the screenshots on the store didn't really seem to accurately show what single player is like (I never once saw a flying vehicle close up like the screenshots show).The only real issue is it is a GFWL title with all the baggage thats brings.  Personally had no problems with this but many others seem to have, and of course there's no guarantee how much longer GFWL will remain around so play it while you can.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												'GTA' meets 'Demolition man' on Mars. Guerilla delivers on the post-apocaliptic/Mad Max'esque scenario despite some lack of variety in the secondary quests. It packs a good 30 hours of destruction to blow some steam on weekends regardless of some occasionnaly frustrating game mechanics (enemies seem to pop up randomly out of nowhere in most high alert situations, and some of the stronger buildings will hold on forever on indestructible structures). Although the tension from the original game is missing as well as the solid FPS element, driving tanks and heavy mechs makes it up for the lack of subtlety. And the steam edition has an extra campaign where you get to be a marauder.If Volition teamed up with id, they would make the perfect RAGE 2 game we all deserve.

Posted: October 23, 2013
												Red Faction Guerrilla is an amazing game by Volition, and they decided to make a sandbox game as opposed to a linear first person shooter.What Guerrilla brings to the table is it's primary selling point, it's destruction system. Which is so well implemented I'm extremely surprised it was never really focused on in games since then. The game allows you to destroy literally every building in the game with it's revolutionary destruction mechanic. All the buildings are built with foundations, levels and fall apart due to the strain of gravity. So it takes a great deal of strategy inorder to destroy a building using as minimal resources as possible. Indeed much of the mission structure and sidequests in the game revolve entirely around the destruction mechanic. Add to that it has an engaging world to explore. Full of little niche references to the original while maintaining a totally different stylistic design. There are of course elements from other games like cars and firefights but it pales in comparison to the well incorporated destruction mechanic. Believe me, once you destroy your first building you will go on an odyssey to return Mars back to a desolate wasteland.Thankfully RFG has had Games For Windows Live patched out. So now you can play it and it's multiplayer properly. I can't recommend this game enough.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												God yes I recommend this game!This is perhaps the most definitive -- for me -- example of "bubble wrap popping fun."  It's not deep, but it's well balanced as a shooter and it's just oodles of fun with how much you can destroy.  Destroy, destroy, destroy.  It's just plain fun.It's mindless in most ways, so if you're looking for an epic story this is not it.  It's also not a brand spanking new game: I had it on the PS3 in 2009 or so, and played it to completion then.That said, the graphics get the job done, and it doesn't feel dated to me at all.  The shift to the PC format is a huge step up over the console version I previously played.  I usually play shooters on the PC anyway, so this just feels more natural.Two examples from my previous playthrough that really stand out to me to this day:1. There was this big armored fortress in I think the second sector.  The thing was enormous, had all sorts of vehicles, guys on towers, you name it.  I spent hours going around the thing accomplishing other missions, and then finally decided I wanted to crack that nut.  I must have tried it 30 different ways, but finally I deduced a weak spot, breached the wall, set charges, went through absolute chaos, stole an enemy vehicle, caused more chaos, and somehow escaped.  Goodbye, giant fortress!  And the game remembers; it's one way to progress in the game, with these sorts of optional "side quests" (for lack of a better term.2. The other thing that really stuck out to me was in one of the last sectors, maybe 5 or 6.  It was a more dangerous area, and really hilly and comparably complicated to navigate around.  My mission was to assssinate some corrupt businessman who was on the sixth floor of some building.  He was up there having a meeting, and would be exiting to I believe a gunship soon.  So, my mission is to kill him -- but how?  Some people would go in the building, make their way through carefully, then take out the guy and escape.  Others would prepare an ambush, wait for him, and then spring a trap at the last second before he could get to his gunship.  Me?  I figured out what part of the building he was in, shot out a window semi-quietly, and then launched one of the overly-massive rockets in through the window, knocking out about a quarter of the building through several floors.  Didn't kill the guy, but suddenly I had line of sight on him six floors up, and I took him out.  It was kind of a lucky break in most respects, it would be hard to duplicate.But being able to pull off lucky breaks like that is what makes this game so darn fun.  There isn't one path to completing a lot of the missions because you can carve your way through the buildings and obstacles how you see fit (but not the terrain).  That's just bloody fun.It's not a game that I feel a constant need to play, or will come back to constantly.  But it is very much one that I enjoy, and occasionally will come back to for a romping good time destroying everything I see before me.  One of the more tactile shooters in years.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												This was the second game I've played from the Red Faction franchise, right after the first Red Faction. They promised me destructibel environment, I got destructible environment, and I don't need an atomic reactor to run the game on. Tho sometimes it's a bit clunky, and you can break physics, but overall, destroying a building with only a big♥♥♥♥♥hammer is really fun. And the better your hammer is, the more fun it becomes.Graphics are a'rite. You are on Mars, so it's mostly red. Gives a great atmosphere, so it suits the game well. Sounds are good. Voice actors gave a good and believable act, ambient sounds are cool. Again, suits the atmosphere of the game.Story is while not the strongest, it gives a theme to why you wreck♥♥♥♥♥♥and have fun. You are the member of the Red Faction, a guerrilla movement on the planet Mars fightning against the Earth Defense Forces, or EDF. You have to clear each region before you can advance to the next to liberate them too. There are some storyline missions, but most of them are kind of fillers - destroy a building, ride shotgun for a crazy Red Faction member, bring a car back to the safehouse in a given timeframe, attack a building, defend a building. Thankfully they are varied, so you don't get bored, and not all of them are necessary to liberate an area. With every mission, EDF's presence in the area is weakened, and in the end, usually there's a mission where they retreat to the other area, and the one you've been in is freed. The final battle and the ending is again, not the best, but is really satifying. Gameplay is where it shines. You can destroy basically EVERYTHING. And you have the tools for it. You smach things with your hammer. You explode things with rocket launchers. You have disc-launcher that shoots razorblades. You have a huge arc welder. And then, the best, the nano-forge. It basically melts ANYTHING it comes into contact with. Vehicles, personnel, building, what you want. Hit the thin spot of an airplane, and laugh while you watch it drop to the ground with a huge KABOOM. Other weapons include assault rifles, shotguns, the usual stuff. Most of them have upgrades too. There are a bunch of accessories in the game, like the warp to safehouse (good when you don't want to walk or drive), or the jump-pack. They are useful, but usually being fun is what matters. You can drive some vehicles, ranging from dumpster trucks to rocket launching tanks. Driving is sometimes tricky, and as well defined as in GTA (so to say, not the best), but then again, it's fun. And this is what this game really is: fun. It keeps you entertained, especially if you don't fail some of the missions for like 5-6 times like me. I'm glad I got the Red Faction bundle some time ago, as Guerrilla is one of the most entertaining and fun games I've played in the recent years. A big thumbs up, we can only hope more of this.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2013
												When this game first came out, I was skeptical to say the least.  "Oh great," I thought, "they're making a GTA clone set on Mars and slapping the Red Faction brand on it.  This is going to be bad." Well... I was half right at least.  You can definitely call it "Grand Theft Mars", but it is anything but bad.To put it bluntly, the gameplay on this is just addictive.  I cannot count how many hours I've spent "reappropriating" colonist vehicles for "the cause" then driving them into buildings, through buildings, over people, and so on.  GeoMod + buildings + magic hammer that breaks everything is a winning formula.  You can also replace the hammer with plastic explosives, rocket launchers, cars, tanks, tank weaponry, the bodies of dudes you just hit with your hammer (yes that will take down walls).  RF:G captures the raw destructive joy that was present in the first Red Faction and scales it up in a major way.To be clear, this is a major shift in the Red Faction brand from the previous two titles.  While there is a relatively linear plot, the gameplay is anything but.  This is very much a sandbox title, and yet the game does not suffer for it. On the contrary, the huge number of opportunities for destruction have never been so well presented.  If anything, I would argue that a sandbox game is the ideal way that the destruction-oriented GeoMod engine should be presented.There are, of course, downsides.  The ability to GeoMod the terrain is completely gone for one, though I can see how that would be too complex (and resource intensive) for a game area of this scale.  A number of the weapons are somewhat lacking, particularly the traditional bullet weapons which are only really useful at all due to the never-ending waves of enemy mooks carrying them.  The biggest problem though?  Games For Windows Live, or more specifically the horrible incompatibilities it can cause.  I can barely get this game to not crash outright on Windows 7.  I highly recommend you use a GFWL alternative if at all possible.If you take anything away from this review, it should be this: until the game started crashing on me 100% of the time, RF:G was always installed on my computer.  While it does have a long and rewarding campaign mode, it's also perfect if you just want to kill some time by causing mass destruction and chaos.  I'd not play the game for months, then pick it up for an hour or two just to destroy some buildings, cars, tanks, so on and so forth.  This is an incredibly fun game, and I'd argue the best in the series.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2013
												Note: Games for Windows Live (GFWL) is GONE; it has been completely patched out of the game.Red Faction: Guerrilla is a satisfying mix of an open-world Mars, GTA driving elements, relatively basic shooting mechanics, some unique weapons, and a rather standard rebel-against-the-oppressive-government / corporation story. Recommended for its tough enemies and unique building-destruction mechanics.Mars is really large, even if it might not look that way on the map. There are no bodies of water, despite the terraforming; it is a dusty, rocky, generally red landscape (as you might expect), but generally well-detailed (if occasionally low-res). Vehicles have some decent variety, and the driving is generally entertaining - which is good, since you'll be doing a lot of it. When not driving, you'll be shooting. The shooting mechanics work well enough (though iron sights are strangely bound to F, while melee is right-click – the reverse of most other games I've played). The weapons themselves, while not as insanely fun to use as those in Red Faction: Armageddon, are still great: the Nano rifle instantly vaporizes ANYTHING (including steel beams), but ammo is limited, so pick your shots. The Grinder shoots throwing stars. The Arc Welder can handle mobs with ease, hitting around 8 or 10 enemies at once with a chained electrical field.The enemy AI and weapon damage provides plenty of challenge for even the most mundane task. Unless you find and seize an actual tank (which is possible!), you won't be able to “tank” anything. Playing Rambo style will get you killed fast. If you like to camp and shoot enemies, you'll die just as fast; enemy AI flanks quickly, and does a lot of damage, even if you acquired armor upgrades. The best part is the destructible buildings. If there's a sniper on a roof I could (of course) try shooting him from a distance. Or I could just shoot the beams under him, collapsing the building and killing him instantly. Not everything is completely satisfying. Vehicles are floaty and hard to control. They're manageable during most missions, but challenge changes to annoyance in several of the timed “drive-this-vehicle-back-to-the-safehouse” missions. This would be a minor nit-pick if driving weren't such a large part of the game. Save points don't save your location in the world; they save you to the nearest safe-house. The constant red landscape is cool and all, but it can get visually boring after a while. Red Faction: Guerrilla is a great game that gives you some trucks, some guns, and tells you to go free the planet from the evil forces controlling it. One of the few games to combine challenging enemies with an open world. Worth noting is that when THQ went bankrupt, the Red Faction franchise and IP was purchased by Nordic Games. Nordic has undertaken extensive patching in recent months, removing Games For Windows Live (replacing it with Steamworks), adding DirectX 11 support (DX9 mode still exists for those who need it), stability patches, a field-of-view setting, new multiplayer maps, the Reconstructor from Red Faction: Armageddon, and many more. At this time, Nordic is very interested in maintaining this franchise, and with developer Volition saying they'd love to do another Red Faction game, we might not have seen the last game of this franchise.

												When this game first came out, I was skeptical to say the least.  "Oh great," I thought, "they're making a GTA clone set on Mars and slapping the Red Faction brand on it. GeoMod + buildings + magic hammer that breaks everything is a winning formula.  You can also replace the hammer with plastic explosives, rocket launchers, cars, tanks, tank weaponry, the bodies of dudes you just hit with your hammer (yes that will take down walls).  RF:G captures the raw destructive joy that was present in the first Red Faction and scales it up in a major way.To be clear, this is a major shift in the Red Faction brand from the previous two titles.  While there is a relatively linear plot, the gameplay is anything but.  This is very much a sandbox title, and yet the game does not suffer for it. On the contrary, the huge number of opportunities for destruction have never been so well presented.  If anything, I would argue that a sandbox game is the ideal way that the destruction-oriented GeoMod engine should be presented.There are, of course, downsides. content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												Pozitívumok:Singleplayer:A pusztítás: A játéknak kifejezetten újító motorja volt régen induláskor. A csak nem földig rombolható objektumok, többnyire épületek elpusztítása a különböző fegyverekkel kifejezetten élvezetes. A fizika persze a földön megszokottaktól eltérő révén, a Marson vagyunk. Ettől függetlenül kifejezetten élvezetes tud lenni Külcsín:Jól néz ki a játék, korához képest kifejezetten tetszetős grafikával rendelkezik, és nem mellékesen kifejezetten jó látványvilága van, már amennyit egy Mars felszínéből ki lehetett hozni. Ötletek:A játék látszik, hogy szeretné a motorját a lehető legjobban kihasználtatni a játékossal. Erre rengeteg lehetőségünk lesz feladatok vagy csak lehetőségek terén. Technológia:Tetszik az a repertoár, amit a játék felsorakoztat. Az alapvető robbantó fegyverektől kezdve a kifinomult nanotechnológiás fegyverig sokrétű és fejleszthető arzenállal rendelkezhetünk és ezt magunknak testre is szabhatunk. AI: Az ellenfelek kifejezetten okosak lettek, de bizonyos helyzetekben még is becsaphatóak. Él a fedezék rendszer, amit előre jelzek érdemes mi magunknak is használni, nem véletlenül helyezkednek az EDF katonái. E mellett, ha harcokba bonyolódunk az ellenállás tagjai, ha éppen véletlenül is jár arra egy, amint tudnak a segítségünkre sietnek. Ilyen helyzet lehet az is, amikor nagy pusztaságban sokáig futunk egyedül, mivel elvesztettük gépjárművünket. Akkor általában odafuvarozik az egyik ellenállás tag és átpasszolja nekünk a volánt. Kifejezetten ötletes szerintem. Kihívások: Na az akad bőven a játékban. Akik eléggé Hardcore playernek mondják magukat, azok az elejétől kezdve odafigyelnek, hogy a játék végére meglegyen a 250 EDF láda elpusztítása, (Amiből többet is raktak le, tehát az se gond, ha elsiklik az ember 1-2 mellett.) a 300 Ore kifarmolása (ebből viszont kereken 300 van a játékban.) és a 36 hanganyag megtalálása. Megéri időt fektetni egyébként bárkinek ezekbe a dolgokba, mert kifejezetten sok Salvage-hez juthatunk általuk, amik kellenek a fegyverek és egyéb dolgok fejlesztéséhez. E mellett magában a játékban a mellék küldetések némelyike kifejezetten nehezen jött össze. Különbnél különb módon igyekeztek kihívások elé állítani az embert már jó értelemben. Utazás:Igen ezt a részét a játéknak külön kiemelném. Egyszerűen látni bizonyos kihívásoknál, ahol egy járművet kell leszállítani valamelyik bázisra, hogy okosan vannak felépítve az útvonalak. A domborzat, a küldetés irányába jelző útvonalat gyakran elterelésnek használták, amire érdemes odafigyelni, mert gyakran a jelzett útvonal hosszabb a kelleténél és ilyenkor élelmesnek kell lenni, hogy megtalálja azokat a lehetőségeket, amiket felhasználhat rövidítésként. Hangulat: A hangulatot, a karakterünk szerepét, mint a gerilla szerepét nagyon könnyen át lehet érezni az ottani viszonyok miatt, és időnként kifejezetten hangulatos volt, amikor győzelmet arattunk egy nehezen bevehető terület felett. Multiplayer:Barátokkal kifejezetten szórakoztató és vicces tud lenni.Pályák/Játékmódok:Kifejezetten sokrétű és változatosra sikerült mind pályák, mind játékmódok tekintetében a multiplayer. Unlocks:Van módod Multiplayeren belül változtatni a kezdő felszerelésed.Negatívumok:Singleplayer:Történet:Kifejezetten gyenge, unalmas, kiszámítható és repetitív lett.Játékmenet:Ha időnként nem csinálna mást az ember, mondjuk egy véletlen event erejéig akkor könnyen rá lehetne unni a repetitív játékmenetre. Pusztíts, utazz, pusztíts, utazz, de az igazság az, ha az ember túl lát ezen a dolgon és próbálja átadni magát a történetnek, akkor mást nem is tudna tenni talán még a valóságban sem, mint ezt itt a játékban. Ugyanakkor...A "társak":Nem egyszer kívántam a "segítségemre" jövő "társaim" halálát... Volt, hogy szemrebbenés nélkül felrobbantottak egy házzal... Volt, hogy tűzharc közepén hátba lőttek nem is egyszer. És segíteni, mint ténylegesen segíteni? Sosem fognak rendesen, sőt a legtöbbször az útban vannak, mert követnek és mennek veled mindenhova, amíg le nem rázod, vagy "véletlenül" meg nem ölöd őket. Mindenki csicskása vagy:Nem lehet ezen szépíteni, egyszerűen rád lett bízva a Mars és ennyi. Mindenki más csak dísznek való, kivétel a mellékesen fegyverekben és technológiában minket segítő nő. Na meg egyetlen egyszer a játék vége felé a Marauderek voltak hasznosak. (Mondhatni semleges és még sem teljesen semleges frakció. Őket csíptem a cuccaik miatt eléggé Badass életérzés.) Lényegében pedig minden küldetést egyedül végzel, kivéve akkor, amikor más a sofőr és neked kell tüzelned.Fizika:Igen sajnos akadt, de mondjuk csak ritkán, problémám a fizikával. Különösen akkor, amikor escort küldetéseket kellett csinálni. (Kimenteni egy EDF katonái által őrzött épületből maximum 3 embert.) Ezek az emberek ugyebár sérülnek rendesen, ezzel semmi gond nincs, ha erősen odacsapódsz egy járművel, mondjuk a falnak akkor érthető, ha mondjuk, az egyik ember kizuhan a gépágyú állványból, de akkor meg mi a nyavalya van, amikor egyenes úton MAGÁTÓL meghal a delikvens? Egyszer csak annyit láttam, hogy felkiált és kirepül holtan. Egyenes úton, sehol senki az égvilágon. Az ellenség:Sejthető, hogy bizony eléggé keményen odatudnak csapni, amikor brutális létszámbeli fölénnyel rendelkeznek, és ez bizony gyakran előfordul. A társak ott vannak, de leginkább golyófogónak. Ezért eléggé nehezek tudnak lenni a tűzharcok. SOSE rohanjunk egy tűzharc közepébe, hamar véget ér a pályafutásunk, ha nem tudunk fedezékbe vonulni. Az ellenfél meg kifejezetten ügyes, darál rendesen azzal, amije van. Fegyverek: Nos, a tuningolható fegyverekkel nem volt bajom, de a nem tuningolhatókkal viszont igen. Szükségesek, mert ezek többsége gyalogság ellen van, ami kifejezetten hasznos tud lenni bármikor, viszont a lőszer mennyiség erőteljesen korlátoz. Mindig rohangálni kell a holttestek között további tárakért, mert hamar ki tud fogyni az ember. Multiplayer:Sajnos be kell látni, de a multiplayer halott.Windows Live:Nos, tudjuk, hogy történt vele egy és más, de szükséges ahhoz, hogy tudjon az ember Multiplayert játszani, nem mellékesen a Singleplayerben Achievmenteket kapjon... A lépések a következőek: Mindenképpen kreálni kell egy új profilt. Ezt követően az Xbox.com oldala fog bejönni ahol a Sign in gombbal egy beléptető oldal fog megjelenni. Ott lentebb lehet látni, hogy ha nincs Live profilod, akkor az ott kéken kiemelt szövegben felajánlja a regisztrációra a lehetőséget. Megcsinálod a profilodat, aktiválod az e-mail címedről és utána a játékon belül lehet, párszor újra be kell lépned vele, ha eddigiekben már csináltál offline profilt, de végül érdemes belépni ezzel a fiókkal, így a rendszer érzékeli a játékon belüli teljesítményedet, nem mellékesen tudni fogsz multizni. Könnyedén lehet egyébként, ha vannak barátok, akikkel nyomulhatsz, de egyébként nehézkes a dolog. Nálam például a NAT úgy érzékeli nincs nyitva, aminek hála korlátoltan tudok "regionálisan" játszani. Összességében pedig a játékot önmagában tudom ajánlani, a singleplayer a maga gyengeségei mellett még mindig szórakoztató és számomra minden perce megérte már csak a tonnányi pusztítás és zúzás miatt is. :D Viszont ha multiplayer tekintetében venné meg az ember, akkor számolnia kell azzal, hogy kihalt oldalakat fog találni, de ha vannak barátok, velük jó szórakozást nyújthat a multiplayer.

Posted: December 6, 2014
												With Red Faction: Guerrilla, players return to Mars to once more stir up trouble in an open-world game promising unheralded destruction from a third-person perspective. GFWL has been removed and the game has been integrated into Steam - Multiplayer, Achievements and all! Plenty of other games have done destructible environments, but never to this degree. Not only is virtually every man-made item in the game breakable, it breaks in detail. When you take your sledgehammer to a wall you break away the outer shell first, then you start digging into the concrete, and finally you hit rebar. Not only is the game's destruction fun to deliver and watch, but it also has a pretty big impact on how you play the game. When tasked with an assassination, you can sneak in and shoot the target or just take down the whole building the person is in. Tired of enemies sending reinforcements over a bridge? Take down the whole bridge. The level of destruction in Red Faction: Guerrilla deepens gameplay in ways I never would have imagined! Your best friend is the sledgehammer! The coolest looking is the singularity bomb which sucks the surrounding area into a small gravity well. Did I mention open world and massive scale? You can roam around and unlock new areas, new missions, new weapons. You get to demolish entire towns and design all the destruction as you see fit. My personal opinion is that this installment is the best one out of all the current Red Faction games!

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												Quick tip if you bought the game and have start up crashing! Try using a Launch Option argument on Steam "-nod3d10"-> Right click Red Faction: Guerilla -> Go to Properties -> in GENERAL, click "SET LAUNCH OPTIONS..." -> Type '-nod3d10' into the text field. This solution worked for me and I hope it helps if you have the same issue!===Before reading my review, my time on record in the game is low because I originally played and completed just about all of the game on PlayStation 3. However I managed to do a lot of things in the PC version in my roughly fifty minutes of play.This game was quick to become my favorite of the series, and one of my favorite games of all time. I played the original Red Faction A LOT way back in the day. My friend and I absolutely loved the first one.I think Red Faction Guerilla is an amazing sequel to the original game that started terrain deformation in videogaming.The story is fantastic,The graphics even for a 2009 videogame are still stunning!It runs great and smooth as well and I'd have to say it's really well optimized.More recent pro, Volition is ditching GFWL to use Steamworks instead. The destruction engine, GeoMOD 2.0. (Although, not the same as the original GEOMOD, it does however have really fun building destruction capabilities and that makes up for it in an OPEN WORLD game.)Did I mention the game is open world?The beloved Rail Gun is still in here, too! As well as weapons very much similar to previous games as well as completely new ones.!!! Great game for stress relief because let's face it. What's more fun than swinging a sledge hammer around tearing a building apart and smashing EDF soldiers? !!!Is that not enough of an incentive to buy it? Aside from, the price on sale events? LIKE RIGHT NOW?The only major issue with the game is that it will crash on start up at some point namely because of the DirectX 10. I'm not entirely sure why but I was able to cure my issue was to set a lcommand line launch parameter of -nod3d9.  Every single issue I had with the game was cured. No crashing, either. I can't fault the publisher or developer for it though. For me, I see a positive visual change by disabling D3D10 because the sun no longer shines through solid objects (and it was blinding) and a few other things I could mention but can't because I was never able to keep the game running long enough.The amount that I recommend this game is tenfold unending. The game is definitely worth even paying the regular non sale price!10/10

Posted: November 24, 2016
												This is an open-world third-person shooter (it even has cover mechanics- not that you should notice them...) that doesn't try to weigh you down with such amenities as "good plot" and "well-developed characters."It's a game about blowing things up. It has about as much to do with guerilla warfare as the sun does with fire - in the loosest terms only.That said, it's an incredibly fun game even if it might look ugly and play mediocrely compare to more modern shooters. Most certainly worth the buy due to decent replay value.As such, I'm nominating the game for a "whoa dude" award because it is so uniquely good at getting money on what is essentially its lone unique selling point: the ability to shred anything and everything manmade. It is a game that feeds off our most basic human instinct - the will to blow things up just for the sake of watching it blow up.Oh, and it also has a really subtle moral narrative about the nature of good and evil that's about as impressive as Spec Ops: The Line's much more obvious narrative... but that's for you to discover.9/10

content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												With Red Faction: Guerrilla, players return to Mars to once more stir up trouble in an open-world game promising unheralded destruction from a third-person perspective. GFWL has been removed and the game has been integrated into Steam - Multiplayer, Achievements and all! Plenty of other games have done destructible environments, but never to this degree. Not only is virtually every man-made item in the game breakable, it breaks in detail. When you take your sledgehammer to a wall you break away the outer shell first, then you start digging into the concrete, and finally you hit rebar. Not only is the game's destruction fun to deliver and watch, but it also has a pretty big impact on how you play the game. When tasked with an assassination, you can sneak in and shoot the target or just take down the whole building the person is in. Tired of enemies sending reinforcements over a bridge? Take down the whole bridge. The level of destruction in Red Faction: Guerrilla deepens gameplay in ways I never would have imagined! Your best friend is the sledgehammer! The coolest looking is the singularity bomb which sucks the surrounding area into a small gravity well. Did I mention open world and massive scale? You can roam around and unlock new areas, new missions, new weapons. You get to demolish entire towns and design all the destruction as you see fit. My personal opinion is that this installment is the best one out of all the current Red Faction games!

content:
Posted: July 6, 2012
												The story is paper thin and laughable, just like the walls of buildings you'll be knocking down with your Mjolnir-like sledgehammer.  But the combat and physics are top notch; it's SO satisfying when enemies are entrenched in buildings to just destroy the entire building instead of carefully sneaking through each corridor and hallway.  The campaign is long and varied and I've found myself setting RF:G down for several months, then reinstalling it just to play through again and laugh in delight as I set elaborate traps up for the security forces foolish enough to mess with me.  There's a few failings in the game, but I feel nitpicky pointing them out.  Sometimes the AI is dumb.  The in-game grass has a laughably short drawing distance, making it look like the ground is kind of boiling while you drive across it.  And while the missions are varied, some are just annoyingly long with frustratingly few checkpoints.  Overall, it's a great game.  Fun, mindless destruction on a huge map.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2013
												Okay. I decided I needed to give Red Faction 3 (this game) another chance. I'm loving it. It's like GTA, but it's on Mars and it's fun. You don't really wander aimlessly (as my previous review states) doing odd jobs. You just do mission for the Red Faction. It's fun, challenging, and... just FUN. I can't strees enough that this is like GTA, except it's fun.I guess my problem with the GTA series has always been the lack of direction. It's TOO sandboxy. I loves me a good sandbox, but GTA just felt like there was no driving plot. No real reason to do one thing over another. RFG has a very central plot. There are some side missions, but it's not a game full of side missions with a plot thrown in that you can follow if you want.It feels like they took the GTA engine and decided to make an actual game with it. For me, this is even better than Saints Row (another, more blatant GTA clone). That series has some drive, but still no real "story" to be followed.RFG hits you with action and plot right off the bat, and gets you involved in what's going on in the game setting pretty quickly (if clumsily). The lack of cinematics is almost a blessing. The few in the beginning are just painful to watch.Like many games on Steam, this one does not work with a gamepad. Let me re-state that. This game doesn't get my usual gamepad complaint, but it's equally non-compliant with how I want to use my gamepad (which is not odd in any way).I had everything working perfectly (so I thought), until I got into a vehicle for the first time. Suddenly, my look up/down axis inverted and there's no option to fix that. Rather, I already fixed it. I wanted my look up/down axis to be inverted (for some reason, "inverted" means "when I push the control stalk up, my head points up"), so I set it that way immediately. I can switch it back and forth each time I get in/out of a truck, but there's no option to make it be the same in both places.So I'm stuck with mouse-and-keyboard for this action game. The upside is I can turn very fast; the down side is I can't move slowly.Some other good things about the control scheme. Both "zoom/aim" and "crouch" can be set to toggle as opposed to hold. Personally, I feel that this is the best way of doing things. There's nothing more complicated than holding down ctrl (to crouch), alt (to walk slow), Z (to aim), S (to walk backward) and A (to walk left). Okay, fine. But it takes a bit of brain power to release the correct key to stop doing just one of those things while continuing to do all the others while tracking targets and avoiding enemy fire. Much better for crouch and aim to be set to toggle instead of hold. Also, reloading automatically stops aiming and sprinting automatically stops crouching. Awesome brain savers.I do wish "aim" was bound to right-click by default (as in Borderlands) instead of to F, but I understand why they did it that way. And if it really becomes irksome, I can switch my keybinds. Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ a console-to-PC port that lets you swap the mother♥♥♥♥ing keybinds. I get that this game is over two years old, but I just wanted to point out how far things have back-slid. Thes console-to-PC port not only has keybind options IN-GAME, but it has mouse-keyboard controls that work properly and don't limit your functionality (Space Marine is absolutely unplayable without a gamepad because of how the mouse-keyboard camera control "works").So I retroactively give RFG a B-. The fact that I can't use my gamepad is a big deal, but I'm still really enjoying the game.

												Back when the game came out i never managed to properly play it, since the first PC version which used GFWL was just a mess but that has finally changed.No more Games For Windows Live instead it uses Steam now, lots of bug fixes, better optimization,updated compatibilaty with latest Windows OS',Steamworks achievements,Steam powered Multiplayer and DX10 replaced with DX11.Destructability in this game is still the best we've ever had in gaming to date, yeah texture quality,polygon count and lighting effects are now somewhat dated but it still look pretty solid visualy even for today's standarts, in my opinion at least.Gunplay doesn't really feel all that good, missions are very repetetive, side missions are just the same 3-5 missions repeated 100 times in the open world of Mars and since it's Mars, most of the enviroment is of course the same which makes it somewhat dull to look at, as you roll into a new sector to liberate just for it to look almost the same as the last place and the story is forgetable and not worth paying attention to.However the thing that holds this game is the what i mentioned earlier on, the amazing destructibility, watching as every lil' piece of a big building colides into another big building, all parts reacting properly and than crumbling into tiny bits is just a blissful joy to watch and makes me wish we had more games with such an amazing destructo physics engine.It's totally worth picking up just because of this amazing tech, it's so much fun slaming a giant truck into a military base filled with explosives and then detonating it and watching it all blow up in a wonderfull way.The game is only 9.99 Euros and during sales it drops to just 4 euros, sometimes even only 1.50 Euros and it's well worth the lil' amount of money it asks from you, even thought it does have alot of flaws.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2011
												The Red Faction: Guerrilla single player campaign follows a formula similar to the always entertaining game Just Cause 2.  You are presented with an open world containing endless enemy soldiers, civilians, and rebel allies in a struggle for dominance.  The object is to destroy enemy buildings and resources with your overpowered arsenal of weapons, while avoiding death and collecting resources with which to upgrade your weapons.  The draw of this game over JC2 is that there are some fun physics involved.  Buildings can become unstable when you damage them enough in key locations, and will callapse somewhat realistically, so you can plan your attacks to minimize required ammo and bring things down as quickly as possible.  There are also lots of missions that progress the story and keep you focused.RF:G has several multiplayer modes that make for some great post-game smack talk.  Taking out an enemy sniper by blowing up the tower he was standing on has never felt better.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2013
												When this game first came out, I was skeptical to say the least.  "Oh great," I thought, "they're making a GTA clone set on Mars and slapping the Red Faction brand on it.  This is going to be bad." Well... I was half right at least.  You can definitely call it "Grand Theft Mars", but it is anything but bad.To put it bluntly, the gameplay on this is just addictive.  I cannot count how many hours I've spent "reappropriating" colonist vehicles for "the cause" then driving them into buildings, through buildings, over people, and so on.  GeoMod + buildings + magic hammer that breaks everything is a winning formula.  You can also replace the hammer with plastic explosives, rocket launchers, cars, tanks, tank weaponry, the bodies of dudes you just hit with your hammer (yes that will take down walls).  RF:G captures the raw destructive joy that was present in the first Red Faction and scales it up in a major way.To be clear, this is a major shift in the Red Faction brand from the previous two titles.  While there is a relatively linear plot, the gameplay is anything but.  This is very much a sandbox title, and yet the game does not suffer for it. On the contrary, the huge number of opportunities for destruction have never been so well presented.  If anything, I would argue that a sandbox game is the ideal way that the destruction-oriented GeoMod engine should be presented.There are, of course, downsides.  The ability to GeoMod the terrain is completely gone for one, though I can see how that would be too complex (and resource intensive) for a game area of this scale.  A number of the weapons are somewhat lacking, particularly the traditional bullet weapons which are only really useful at all due to the never-ending waves of enemy mooks carrying them.  The biggest problem though?  Games For Windows Live, or more specifically the horrible incompatibilities it can cause.  I can barely get this game to not crash outright on Windows 7.  I highly recommend you use a GFWL alternative if at all possible.If you take anything away from this review, it should be this: until the game started crashing on me 100% of the time, RF:G was always installed on my computer.  While it does have a long and rewarding campaign mode, it's also perfect if you just want to kill some time by causing mass destruction and chaos.  I'd not play the game for months, then pick it up for an hour or two just to destroy some buildings, cars, tanks, so on and so forth.  This is an incredibly fun game, and I'd argue the best in the series.

												Imagine if the Portal gun were first introduced as just another weapon in a first person shooter; in half life, for example. You would be excited when you first got it and would be dying to see what kinds of amazing puzzles it can bring. But first you have to go to objective marker #782, kill a bunch of dudes with a rocket launcher. My point is a good game puts its best feature at the core and build a game around it. And that's my problem with Red Faction.When I first started playing this I thought "Can we, like, remove the shootings, the missions, the story, the upgrades and... actually, can I just break♥♥♥♥♥♥uninterruptedly for a while?". The destruction system is so great! I feel like this game has such a nice mechanic and even though it does make extensive use of it, of course, the game doesn't revolve around it, which makes me frustrated most of the time, wanting more destruction and less "take this car to point B in 2 minutes". The fun part is locked inside a shell of generic open world game.That isn't saying the generic open world game is bad. It's ok. It follows all the open world commandments: thou shall complete missions, thou shall liberate regions, thou shall upgrade your♥♥♥♥♥♥etc. But I don't know if it's good enough that I'll finish the campaign. I just quit after a mission where I have to hunt down snipers. I'm trying to beat it by demolishing the building they're on, but it requires too much explosives — more than I can carry at the moment — and the hammer takes too long to do it while being shot at from all sides. I like that I can at least try to do that! but I'm pretty sure it was designed with a more traditional approach in mind, specially considering how well fortified these particular buildings are.I guess I recommend it if you find it in a good sale. As for me, I'm going to check out some videos of the next Red Faction game of the series, to see which direction it went.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2012
												Here you have a sandbox game similar to Just Cause or Mercenaries, but a little more limited in scope and map-size (likely due to the game's age and relatively small development studio) and set on post-terraforming Mars.The two reasons I like it were:A) RevolutionB) DestructionREVOLUTIONIt's a pretty cool setting for any work of fiction.DESTRUCTIONThe introduction mission is just an opportunity to smash things with a super-sledgehammer. You can take out chunks of buildings and watch them collapse as the physics engine takes over. Okay, sometimes a building will be unrealistically supported by a very thin steel girder, but most of the time it is very gratifying to take structures apart piece by piece (by hammer, by explosives, or by driving a massive truck into them).You don't normally get the same level of destructive freedom in an open-world game.There are some missions that don't feel very guerrilla at all. You sometimes find yourself battling/fleeing/baiting the entire EDF by yourself in an all-out-war. These poorly-designed missions, especially the final mission, are the game's terribly low moments.We could have done with more character from the cast - your allies are virtually indistinguishable from one-another, being cookie-cutter guys/girls who turn up randomly to assist you during play. The same goes for your enemies - they are all irredeemably evil sadists.I wouldn't label the title as a "must buy" but I enjoyed blowing up bridges and sabotaging wind farms. Probably says something about me.Pros: smashin' stuffCons: basic gameplay and shallow plot that could do with more polish

												This is truly one of my favourite games.The single player is an invigorating experience like no other, liberating sector after sector and facing increasingly militarized hostility. The way the revolution is played out is up to your choices to upgrade your skills and purchased new weapons, the way you inspired your fellow guerrillas, and your overall combat skills. Driving the surface of terraformed Mars, you are revealed to structure after structure that can be destroyed with whatever means you choose! The freedom Havok physics engine provides is just another fantastic edition to this revolutionary game. With such a stimulating and realistic environment, Red Faction Guerrilla single player provides an extraordinary and unique, freeworld campaign that many other games attempt to strive for. Red Faction Guerrilla achieves this. Its multiplayer is one of the most colourful and sublime multiplayers I've ever played. Instead of the monotonous Call of Duty kill-die-respawn pattern that we've all played before, it allows you to kill creatively with weapons that no other game has ever coneceived but still require tactics to use; not just anybody can pick up the Grinder and slice people up with it. Plus, the multitude of objective gametypes that are found in no other game (simply due to the fact that Red Faction Guerilla is so unlike every other game and therefore its objective gametypes can only be based around RFG's mechanics) adds variety to each game you play. The multiplayer never gets old. It is well worth it. This game's population must be maintained. On the Xbox, its popularity has diminshed a point of no rejuvination. This game is well worth the $20, and when it's on sale don't hesitate to pick it up!

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												This is one of my favorite games of all-time, played for dozens of hours outside of Steam. Bought it again because it was on sale and I was too lazy to look for the CD.It's very similar in basic game design to Grand Theft Auto 3+: Third-person view, missions that start with some job that needs done, a map to reference a waypoint, jump in a vehicle, and head to the objective. But with fully destroyable buildings, piece by piece. Sandbox-like in that regard (it's not actually a sandbox game), but how you place explosives, shoot rockets, or swing your super-hammer is up to you. Watching a tower fall after you blow up the base is just awesome. Or watching it fall after you crash a truck through it. Or watching it fall after an enemy accidentally drives his armored car through it. You can't dig through the terrain, but destroying structures is much more fun. The action is non-scripted and the physics engine leads to some highly entertaining events - I shot an explosive canister that was next to a garage. When it blew up, it tore a hole in the side and the armored car inside was lauched forward, over a steep hill, through the air, and fell through the roof of another building that I needed to take down. After a moment, it exploded. It was like some ultra-violent Rube Goldberg contraption. Completely unexpected and I doubt I could ever reproduce it.Some missions have you steal a vehicle, others will have you defend a building, or rescue hostages. Most will have you destroy something. Plenty of optional missions. Or you can just pick a high-value enemy target and take it out to help lower their level of control of the sector.The storyline is kind of predictable, though there are a few twists here and there. In the original Red Faction, the fairly-evil Ultor mega-corporation is brought down, with the help of the Earth Defense Force. In this game, the EDF has become the cruel occupiers of Mars and they killed your brother.(Not a spoiler, it happens 5 minutes into the game.) Nothing overly creative. And, like too many games these days, there's someone talking to you over a communicator while on missions- Someone who you'll want to find and punch in the face. Guy gives me a mission to rescue some hostages that are about to be executed. I accept the mission and about 4 seconds later I jump into my truck and he starts screaming "Mason! What are you doing? People are DYING!" Holy crap old man, keep your pants on, I haven't even started the truck!But, these a minor issues in light of how fun the game is otherwise. Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												Nothing like a little wanton destruction to kill an hour or two.  That's the only reason to play RF: Guerilla.  It's not the story (which is reminiscent of Total "Get Your♥♥♥♥♥To Mars" Recall) that keeps you playing, it's certainly not the throw-away character development, and it's not even the Games For Windows Live.  It's taking a sledgehammer, clubbing a dude four feet into a Mars precipice, and collapsing a highrise apartment complex from the ground floor.  It's climbing into an industrial loader and walking through a military base like Stallone in Rocky IV, if buildings were Ivan Drago and face-punches were that robot butler.  Maybe that last analogy doesn't make sense...Bottom line is- I fully recommend this game if you grew up watching "Aliens", Schwarzeneggar, or American Gladiator.  Again, maybe not that last one.  Like I said, it wasn't the story that kept me coming back, it wasn't the engine (not the prettiest game by a long shot), and it wasn't the basic game mechanics (driving is hopelessly, but somehow appropriately, floaty to the point of frustration; level design is a lot less open world than many similar games due to impassable mountain ranges; shooting mechanics are inaccurate at best)- it is literally the joy of melting a memorial bridge with a nanite rifle before exploding the rest using remote charges and a saw-blade launcher.  That'll do, pig.  That'll do.Give it a try if you like:-GTA or Saint's Row games-any of the previous Red Faction games with the VMod Destruction technology-Total "Man, I got five kids to feed!" Recall-GTA-style hijacking with a lightning gun (you'll be doing a lot of that!)-the sound of breaking glass-crushing your little brother's dreams along with his block towers

content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												Red Faction: Guerilla was one of my all time favourite games for the XBOX 360. It has the best destruction engine I have ever seen in a game, including Frostbite. And whats more, it was incredibly fun! SIngle player could occationally get repetitive, and the racing mission were such a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥(but I don't like racing in open world games anyway), but the awesome destruction NEVER got old. Throw in some great weapons with which to cause mayhem and you've got yourself bags of fun for hours on end. And that's only the single player the Guerilla multiplayer was one of the most underrated parts of his massively underrated game. It was quick but not twitchy simple but not without lots of strategic and tactical options. Your combination of which superpowered backpack and which gun you chose to use would drastically change your play style. My personal favourite combo was the Rhino pack combined with the electric gun. You could smash through a wall taking out a passing player then finish them off by frying them with the elecric gun. So awesome! I was gutted when the new call of duty came out (whichever one it was at the time) as there seemed to be a mass exodus on  xbox to tath, leaving me and my mates without anyone to play with or against. An unfortunately recurring problem with consoles.So when I saw it on steam I though GREAT! PC gamers are way more likely to keep this online stuff going! Only to find out it was a GFWL game and that it'll be going the way of the dodo very soon. So dissapointing!Red Faction: Guerilla is a brilliant game basically. But with very little incentive to play it any more....such a shame.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												A game about breaking stuff. 'Nuff said.  Or if you're into in-depth reviews... A third person shooter where you play as Alec Mason; a demolitionist, as he and the revoltionary group(The Red Faction) try to overthrow the dictatorship of the Earth Defense Force. By breaking stuff.  As far as third person shooters go, this is a fairly standard game. It has a sandbox feel to it, the map is very open. What sets this game apart from other games though, is the epic level of destruction and physics. That level of breaking stuff is amazing, I haven't found anything that you can't break in this game(Besides the ground, but thats kind of important.). Historically, the Red Faction series has pioneered video game destruction, and this game improves even further upon that idea. The story is meh, but the shooting is tight, and this game really takes advantage of its destruction. Multiplayer is, quite literally, a blast.(Get it, get it?)

												Very good action and destruction game. Graphics are decent and mechanics is wonderfull. Map is sandbox, that brings progressive freedom for movement and choice missions. With a bundle of weapons and a lot of vehicles, all can be driven. All structures can be destroyed by many ways, like with a single great hammer, and later, player can to rebuild at wish if lower parts are intact. Is not exactly a shooter: to play as if it were so, will be frustrating by the scarce of ammo, coverages and infinite enemies. The game concept is enterilly based on The Saboteur, an oddity in videogame industry that few people known. The designers of Red Faction saga always exploit and mix other games of its time and this title is not exception, but maybe is the best of the series. Really fun and therapeutic; just would need a first person view to be perfect. Complete the main and secondary missions and extra campaing assures long time of entertainment. Worth its price.

												      The destruction in this game is what you want here the story over all is pretty by the numbers. The locals are interesting and change up from time to time but Mars is where you shall be stuck.      Combat is good as weapons feel fairly punchy but you die so fast that it can get annoying to have to redo missions many times over from the beggining since there are no mid mission checkpoints unless it is an exceedingly long mission. Everytime you die you also lose a finite resource which isnt the biggest deal every but makes dying more of a pain. Not till the end of the game do you start getting armor that helps a little but you still die way too fast with the Ai's pinpoint accuracy.      GFWL got removed which is very cool and the game also got a nice overal update so if you like taking down buildings brick by brick you cant go wrong here.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
												RFG is a bit of a hard game to play. The controls are a bit floaty and not super tight, the shooting is pretty baseline and the combat in general is frustratingly baseline mixed with bad design. The cover mechanic thats supposed to help you actually is terrible and is more of a issue to work with than just not using it at all.The physics and destruction is top notch. If you just want to break stuff its great for that though.The world is pretty empty aswll. Lots of hills with occasionally some towns or buildings between the hills. The main diffrence between areas being just the paint brush/textures used on the ground.The real star of the show is dynamic destruction and physics modelling of buildings. Which is great, but knocking over legos only stays fun so long and as time goes on it becomes a bit frustrating that you can't just knock over a building with relative ease. The novelty really just wears off because aside from the destruction the rest of the game kinda suffers.The world is interesting but in the game theres not much interesting about it, the world seems astoundigly flat and as boring as a Martian colony can be. Inside of building theres very little details much of the time, partially due to the destruction. Most characters arn't very interesting and all the civilian NPCs your supposed to be fighting for are basically stupid idiots who deserve what they get because they just get in the way.Alot of the assets are also reused in terms of building materials aswell as buildings themselves which makes destroying stuff alot less interesting after you have done quite a bit.Its technically impressive, the problem is its just a flat and rather boring game. It was easy for me to forget about my playthrough and then when I remembered to go "Eugh, naaahhhh" as its just so slow and boring.

content:
Posted: January 16
												I tried this game out around the time it was released and wasn’t able to get into it so I decided to give it another chance now and I’m still not able to enjoy it. It’s one of the first games that started the craze of slowly taking over a giant open world map with very little focus on the actual story. Most games released after this one that have the same open world gameplay loop do a better job like Just Cause 2 and 3 or Mad Max or Assassins Creed Brotherhood and Black Flag, even games released before it like The Godfather for example. A lot of those games also managed to also focus on the story and main missions rather than solely relying on the side content which is what this game does. There is barely a story in this game, it’s mostly just a framework for all the gameplay. For the story that is actually there it is very bland and uninteresting with very generic characters. I didn’t find the gameplay very interesting either, the novelty of the destruction wore off very quickly because it’s pretty much the only thing you are doing and there just isn't enough gameplay variety surrounding the destruction to keep the game engaging. Mars as a location gets very tiresome to drive around, it doesn’t offer visual variety like other open world games. I don’t feel compelled to continue playing this game like I do with pretty much every other game I buy because I feel like I’m not going to get anything out of investing more time into it. Even with games that i consider to be bad i usually bother finishing just so i could see where it goes and what it does but with this game, i just don't care. 4/10 (Mediocre)

content:
Posted: June 27, 2011
												I was obligated to play this game after scoring a free copy of Red Faction: Armageddon. I must admit, I came in a bit skeptical as the very early minutes of the game reminded me of Grand Theft Auto in space. The cars were crappy and its only gimmick was destructible environments.An hour into the game, I found myself loving it. The plot is thin, but the plot was not what kept me playing. It's surprising to see such a simple gimmick go a long way. Not only was watching buildings get demolished fun, this game mechanic forced me to strategize on my feet. It gave me many options to approach a given situation. To my surprise, this was a thinking man's game.If you ever see this game on sale, don't hesitate to purchase it. I picked it up for $5 a year or two back and it has rewarded me with about a dozen hours of fantastic gameplay. I eagerly await for more sequels from this franchise.Grade: B+

 Grand Theft Mars Rover! I already enjoyed this game when it was originally released, the steam edition is even better. Not the epic type of game, because the story/characters/objectives and also the world are rather shallow, but if you´re in the mood for some creative deconstruction or atomizing your friends, Red Faction Guerilla has a lot of interesting tools for the job. Those tools combined with the amazing physics for collapsing buildings manage to make this game something really special. I also like the fast paced vehicle combat. All in all a good game that i´m always coming back to when i want to kill 1-2 hours, go brain afk and cause some chaos.

Posted: June 27, 2011
												I was obligated to play this game after scoring a free copy of Red Faction: Armageddon. I must admit, I came in a bit skeptical as the very early minutes of the game reminded me of Grand Theft Auto in space. The cars were crappy and its only gimmick was destructible environments.An hour into the game, I found myself loving it. The plot is thin, but the plot was not what kept me playing. It's surprising to see such a simple gimmick go a long way. Not only was watching buildings get demolished fun, this game mechanic forced me to strategize on my feet. It gave me many options to approach a given situation. To my surprise, this was a thinking man's game.If you ever see this game on sale, don't hesitate to purchase it. I picked it up for $5 a year or two back and it has rewarded me with about a dozen hours of fantastic gameplay. I eagerly await for more sequels from this franchise.Grade: B+

content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												Red Faction Guerrilla is Volitions version of Grand Theft Auto with a destructible world which makes it better than GTA. But besides that, this is one of many underrated games people played it when it came out and after a year it was completely dead which sucked. So, singleplayer, with the Steam Edition it comes with the dlc that was released for the game back in 2009. And the core game itself takes a few hours to complete but with all the side quests to do it takes up to 10 hours to beat. Which is pretty good for an open world game. The Multiplayer, you can still play with friends thats if your friends have it, but other than that its totally dead you can still play by yourself but it gets boring. And theres an extra storyline to it that takes maybe 5 hours to complete. The Graphics it uses the havok engine which is a pretty good engine for games this big. But for a 2009 game it still delivers. World size, its pretty big almost the same size as GTA and thats it. The combat system is pretty great actually, and the game made a huge transiton from a first person to third person view which people thought was pretty risky. But it delivered suprisngly well. The driving is exactly like grand theft auto almost. This concludes my review. I give the game a 10/10.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2014
												Definitely in my top 5 games of all time. I originally had this on Xbox 360 but recently bought it on PC. The PC version is identical to the console version as far as I can tell. This game offers a unique perspective as a member of a resistance force who cannot fight face to face like in FPS games, but has to use clandestine methods to overcome the enemy.PROS:*Great destructable environment*Unique storyline *Original gameplay*Excellent graphics considering its age*Good range of vehicles*You can crash your car into ANY building and attack anyone: this game offers a lot of freedom to the player, in a similar way to GTA, though simplified. *Open world that is easy to navigate and you can go off-road wherever you want.CONS:*You need to install Games for Windows Live (the Microsoft equivalent of steam) to use and save the game*DO NOT buy this game for the multiplayer experience. There is no multiplayer community and the servers are soon to be shut down. Do not let this put you off however, the singleplayer is great.*It was clearly designed for consoles, so the console experience is generally better.*Missions can be repetitive (they mostly involve blowing stuff up) but because the destructible environment is so good, you don't really mind.To conclude, this game is worth buying if it's on sale, and you could spend a lot of time playing it. However, the game is more suited to console, so if you can, I would recommend buying the game for console rather than PC (though it could be more expensive). If Halo married GTA, this would be their child.

Posted: December 2, 2014
												This game continues to deliver a constant great experience. With a surprisingly good story, an interesting setting and atmospehere, and the beauty of the Geo Mod 2.0 destruction engine, the game will keep you enthralled and playing. Speaking as someone who's only played the game on PS3 before, I can say that it gets even better on PC. There is a somewhat small modding community, but a modding community none the less, who unlock hidden content, make tweaks and even allow to have godmode.Pros: -You can tear builidngs apart, brick by brick using a wide array of weapons-You obtain weapons such as remote charges that can be thrown and exploded at will, a rifle that disintegrates solid matter, a large missle that causes massive damage, a guass rifle, and a whole array of normal combat weapons.-You really feel like you're fighting as part of a rebellion if you play it seriously-There's a large amount of augmented vehicles that can assist you in the rebellion-It's Open World!-It plays out in a territory capturing kind of way. You force enemies out of sectors by lowering their control over the sector and rasing the morale and support for your guerrillas.Cons:-Buildings take quite a long time to collapse. An unrealistic length of time. This can be tweaked with mods though.-Enemies are too powerful, and you can't hold enough ammo to deal with them all.-No checkpoints on any missions-Buildings don't respawn, meaning that you can't go back to destroy them again at the end of the gameI can confidently give this game a 10 of 10. Playing with difficulty enchancing mods can make the game somewhat frustrating when you die repeatedly on missions with no checkpoints.

												3rd person open world shooter, where you basically just go on a rampage around an earth-colonised mars, during a civil war/uprising. Theres some kind of plot, but the destruction mechanics/physics are the highlight, and put most modern games to shame. Do you strategically place shaped charges to weaken the structural integrity of a building, or take a more direct approach with rockets? Or do you simply plow a giant truck straight through it! Oh the possibilities!Theres a large variety of weapons that start off fairly normal but develop into sometihng verging on Saints Row IV, and of course everyones favourite multi-purpose weapon and tool, the sledgehammer!

content:
Posted: April 25, 2014
												Definitely in my top 5 games of all time. I originally had this on Xbox 360 but recently bought it on PC. The PC version is identical to the console version as far as I can tell. This game offers a unique perspective as a member of a resistance force who cannot fight face to face like in FPS games, but has to use clandestine methods to overcome the enemy.PROS:*Great destructable environment*Unique storyline *Original gameplay*Excellent graphics considering its age*Good range of vehicles*You can crash your car into ANY building and attack anyone: this game offers a lot of freedom to the player, in a similar way to GTA, though simplified. *Open world that is easy to navigate and you can go off-road wherever you want.CONS:*You need to install Games for Windows Live (the Microsoft equivalent of steam) to use and save the game*DO NOT buy this game for the multiplayer experience. There is no multiplayer community and the servers are soon to be shut down. Do not let this put you off however, the singleplayer is great.*It was clearly designed for consoles, so the console experience is generally better.*Missions can be repetitive (they mostly involve blowing stuff up) but because the destructible environment is so good, you don't really mind.To conclude, this game is worth buying if it's on sale, and you could spend a lot of time playing it. However, the game is more suited to console, so if you can, I would recommend buying the game for console rather than PC (though it could be more expensive). If Halo married GTA, this would be their child.

I played this game whilst it was on steam for free, so it is not a game I would have bought on my own and won't have as much playtime experience with itOverviewRed Faction Guerrilla feels like a post apocalyptic game set on a distant future earth. No actually, its on mars. The game immediatley shoves the emphasis on fun and being able to destroy everything you see whilst gawping at the games great physics destruction effects. Literally, everything you see that isnt part of the terrian (i.e. cars, buildings, fences) can be destroyed using the various arsenal of weapons including explosive charges and your trusty sledgehammer. The story is nothing particularly exciting and SPOILERS will follow. This game isn't based on giving you an intense, jaw dropping story based ecperience and has a pretty run-of-the-mill sotryline. The world is basically being held captive by an opressive evil government, your brother is part of the resistance group and he gets killed in pretty much the opening cutscene (the second one). END OF SPOILERS The characters that the game throws at you are pretty run of the mill, but that in no way ruins the experience of the game. It delivers satisfying destruction and fun gunplay and should not be ignored. Positive+ Great Destruction+ Graphics are OK+ Fun GameplayNegative- Boring Story- Un-interesting CharactersConclusionIf you are looking for a story driven epic, just ignore this game. If you are looking to blow some stuff up and have a little bit of fun, then this game is probably a safe bet for you.

 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine Red Faction: Guerrilla is a game developed by Volition Studios and originally published by the now defunct company THQ, now published by THQ Nordic (or Nordic Games) and is also the third game in the Red Faction series Red Faction: Guerrilla is an action packed third person shooter which follows up from the previous Red Faction II game and continues the Red Faction story lineHowever, this time the game moves from a linear gameplay and goes open world which was my least favourite gameplay change in the Red Faction seriesThe gameplay is pretty standard, but lots of fun and you also have a new nifty magnet gun and some powers with the Nano ForgeOnce again the highlight of the Red Faction series is blowing stuff up, and you can blow up all the structures and also repair things since enemies will often be attacking you and stairs and other things you need to access will be goneOverall, this game is a lot of fun and for what it is - you'll have a blast playing by blowing things up and fighting off evil cultists and aliens RECOMMENDED :)
