												A perfect example of how Windows Live sucks the hind♥♥♥♥♥and ruins a perfectly good game. Red Faction: Guerrilla is a near perfect blend of tactical combat and sandbox smash-em-up, objectives throughout the game involve smashing, crashing, exploding and otherwise completely vandalizing EDF structures and key buildings, you can't help the mirthful smirk across your face when you see a building collapse after dropping two mines on it. Combat objectives come to you via radio informing you of guerrilla warfare or simple defense missions. While purely optional it's a good idea to play through these portions as it provides you with experience, salvage and otherwise keeps the game fresh. The storyline is uncompelling to say the least and the shading is awful resulting in an ugly, bright world. Posted: December 28, 2014
												I cannot recommend this game enough. The destruction and physics are incredibly fun just to mess around with, there are cool space vehicles that resemble the lunar rover that was used on the moon in the 60's, and there are MOTHER♥♥♥♥ING MECHS that can WALK RIGHT THROUGH THE WALL OF A BUILDING, JUST LIKE THE KOOL-AID GUY! OH YEAH! Not only that but the game is somehow incredibly well optimized for the sheer amount of physics implemented into the game's engine. It's like it literally runs on magic. The devs did a really great job. The only gripes I can possibly think of are very easily fixed with mods. Once you destroy something, it's destroyed for good. However, there's a mod that brings the reconstructor gun into single player, so you can continuously have fun destroying and rebuilding whatever you want. Also, the mechs only happen a few times through the single player story and are very sparse, but as I understand, there are mods that place these mechs in various locations throughout the map for you to use. Worth every penny, if you don't already own this game you better fix that.

												A perfect example of how Windows Live sucks the hind♥♥♥♥♥and ruins a perfectly good game. Red Faction: Guerrilla is a near perfect blend of tactical combat and sandbox smash-em-up, objectives throughout the game involve smashing, crashing, exploding and otherwise completely vandalizing EDF structures and key buildings, you can't help the mirthful smirk across your face when you see a building collapse after dropping two mines on it. Combat objectives come to you via radio informing you of guerrilla warfare or simple defense missions. While purely optional it's a good idea to play through these portions as it provides you with experience, salvage and otherwise keeps the game fresh. The storyline is uncompelling to say the least and the shading is awful resulting in an ugly, bright world. But none of this matters when Windows Live in on the scene, so Windows: Go find yourself the queens plastic sex toys and literally "go royally f*ck yourself".

content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												First off: Don't be put off by my playtime. I own this game as a retail version and re-bought it on Steam.Red Faction Guerilla is an open world game. It takes place on mars which is being colonialized by mankind and civilization there is currently in the state of terraforming and mining (so don't expect a city like you would in a GTA game or similar). That said, there is a fairly big map to explore with a whole lot of buildings, machines and structures which are fully destroyable. There are driveable vehicles and a small amount of weapons (of which some are very fun to play around with). There are RPG elements like the upgrading of weapons, health and some other useful things. Besides the main story missions (of which I don't want to spoil one bit), you can take on challenges, collect and destroy stuff to be able to buy upgrades. The story is not bad, but the focus in this game really lies on exploring and destroying..and if you're in for that, this is a straight buy for you.By the way: The game was recently patched and got full Steamworks integration alongside with new MP-maps and a great community :)

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Red Faction Guerrilla is a free-roaming third person action game set on Mars. This game departs from the FPS genre and while that might offput some (it did for me at first, but I got over it), it does well to distance itself from the failure of Red Faction 2.Red Faction Guerrilla is one of the few games that I've actually played to completion. I loved the original Red Faction FPS game, can't say the same for RF2 and I was hoping this game would restore the franchise. In the spirit of the original Red Faction, Red Faction Guerrilla totes a physicals engine that allows for physics based destruction of buildings. Unlike the original Red Faction, this game actually does produce gameplay around this aspect. The building destruction physics is fairly well executed and destroying buildings can be extemely satisfying.8/10

content:
Posted: August 31, 2013
												You ever remember going to the beach and kicking down a sandcastle?  That sheer, cathartic joy of structural destruction crying out to the gorilla in the cockles of your heart, lifting it as that ever so ephemeral archetecture was undone by your besandled foot?  That's this game.  That is so this game at any given point.  Hammer, car, rocket launcher, remote mines.  Car covered in remote mines full of propane tanks propelled by rocket launcher.  All structures are yours to unmake and the joy of it is splendid.   The graphics and soundtrack are about standard, nothing to deride or write home about, but the gameplay.  THE GAMEPLAY.  Beat the game and you get fun cheats to sandbox destroy the surface of mars and everything on it.  The story mode is tolerable and when set to hard enough difficulty actually kinda fun to play through.  The side missions are the oven fresh cornbread next to that cold chicken that is the story mode.  Rescuing hostages in building, destroying a building with the missions weapon of choice, causing as much destruction as possible.  Brilliant gameplay and standard everything else a game needs to be shipped out all in this package.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												Most fun I've had blowing stuff up, driving into stuff, crashing into stuff, whacking stuff, knocking over stuff... you get the point. Pros: -Intriguing story, makes you want to finish the game-Extremely realisitc physics*-All buildings are destructible, sometimes I go into a new world and turn on the cheats and blow everything to pieces with the thermobaric rocket... what fun!-Easy to use controls-Open world enviroment, work on the main storyline or complete minor guerrilla actions-Blowing stuff to pieces, who doesn't enjoy that!-Runs REALLY good on low end machines if you turn down the graphics. My laptop barely gets any framerates in most games, like Garry's Mod or TF2, but this game, even with super low graphics settings blew my expectations out of the park, well still looking amazing. I can't even boot up Call of Duty: AW on lowest settings, this game got me 60+. Very well optimized.Cons: -*The physics on buildings are extremely realisitc, as long as the building/piece isn't connected to the ground in some way. A giant building can be supported by a single framing wall. No, not a reinforced steel pillar, not a metal frame, but just wall material. Not even concrete. So we are talking about a multi ton building being kept up by a single piece of plaster on the edge of the buliding. GG. As soon as you hit this plaster, the building falls and looks amazing. Overall 9.5/10. I enjoyed the heck out of the free weekend, and finished the main story in about 10 hours. It will probably take you another 10 hours to finish the rest of the guerilla actions, as well as another 24 hours to complete/mess around with all the other gamemodes. And for 4 dollars on sale, it's nice and cheap. I recommend.tl dr; blowing stuff up is fun m8 buy this

content:
Posted: August 31, 2013
												You ever remember going to the beach and kicking down a sandcastle?  That sheer, cathartic joy of structural destruction crying out to the gorilla in the cockles of your heart, lifting it as that ever so ephemeral archetecture was undone by your besandled foot?  That's this game.  That is so this game at any given point.  Hammer, car, rocket launcher, remote mines.  Car covered in remote mines full of propane tanks propelled by rocket launcher.  All structures are yours to unmake and the joy of it is splendid.   The graphics and soundtrack are about standard, nothing to deride or write home about, but the gameplay.  THE GAMEPLAY.  Beat the game and you get fun cheats to sandbox destroy the surface of mars and everything on it.  The story mode is tolerable and when set to hard enough difficulty actually kinda fun to play through.  The side missions are the oven fresh cornbread next to that cold chicken that is the story mode.  Rescuing hostages in building, destroying a building with the missions weapon of choice, causing as much destruction as possible.  Brilliant gameplay and standard everything else a game needs to be shipped out all in this package.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2015
												8/10: You are a Terrorist similator.Basically Red Faction: Guerilla is a 3rd person sort of open world shooter set on mars with a heavy, heavy focus on destruction.Do you like blowing up/leveling buildings? Well, if so there is litterally no better game for you that isn't an indie game.The shooting is relatively passable, the weapons interesting, the graphics are definitely suitable, and the story is kind of meh. There's driving vehicles, which handle relatively well although one or two early missions involving them are rather annoying.The destruction though? Well, it doesn't always follow the laws of physics but it's fully functional and fully worth it. The game is basically Just Cause 2 with the tropical setting replaced with mars and the focus on movement and all around freedom replaced with a high fidelity destruction system and sci-fi weapons.If you're considering buying this game, it's $20 so you'll probably be getting your money's worth on this one. The Steam Edition guarentees that it will run on your system without trouble. The multiplayer, while fun, is pretty much dead right now, but it is still fully fuctional in case you get some curious friends together.Reccomendation: If you're interested, buy it.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2015
												8/10: You are a Terrorist similator.Basically Red Faction: Guerilla is a 3rd person sort of open world shooter set on mars with a heavy, heavy focus on destruction.Do you like blowing up/leveling buildings? Well, if so there is litterally no better game for you that isn't an indie game.The shooting is relatively passable, the weapons interesting, the graphics are definitely suitable, and the story is kind of meh. There's driving vehicles, which handle relatively well although one or two early missions involving them are rather annoying.The destruction though? Well, it doesn't always follow the laws of physics but it's fully functional and fully worth it. The game is basically Just Cause 2 with the tropical setting replaced with mars and the focus on movement and all around freedom replaced with a high fidelity destruction system and sci-fi weapons.If you're considering buying this game, it's $20 so you'll probably be getting your money's worth on this one. The Steam Edition guarentees that it will run on your system without trouble. The multiplayer, while fun, is pretty much dead right now, but it is still fully fuctional in case you get some curious friends together.Reccomendation: If you're interested, buy it.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2016
												(NOTE: I have spent more time than Steam says I have, I had a disk version of the game, but RFG used to use Games for Windows Live, but I bought the steam copy because Games for Windows Live went offline a while ago)Mix GTA 5 and Just Cause 3, and throw Mars in there, and you get this game, which is a great game, here's why.The main thing about this game is its destruction, It's the main thing that players think when they think of this game. Almost every building except a few small bridges in the late game areas are able to be destroyed. Sadly, the actual ground itself isn't destructible. And the buildings actually get destroyed dynamically, there is no special animation that plays when a building is too damaged to be able to sustain itself, so the building will fall randomly depending on how it's been damaged, where it's been damaged and what it's been damaged by, which is great. I think you get the point on the destruction and that the destruction in this is amazing.Plot: The plot is meh, I can understand it but it's pretty basic. Since this is a sequal, I won't say what goes on in the previous game.  So, the Earth Defense Force owns Mars and is opressing the people of Mars. You, Alec Mason, went to Mars to mine and earn some profit. But your Brother, Dan Mason, is shot dead by the EDF. Alec Mason, wanting revenge, joins the Red Faction, the group that Dan Mason was in. the Red Faction is also a resistance group fighting the EDF. So, Alec Mason goes around, liberating provinces the 6 Provinces of mars (Parker, Dust, Badlands, Oasis, Free Fire Zone and Eos). I'll refrain from any more spoilers, if you want the ending, either watch a video or play the game to the end.Campaign gameplay: So, you go around the 6 provinces, doing guerilla actions and destroying EDF buildings to raise the Red Factions morale, and lower EDF control. Once you complete all the story missions in a province (Not the guerrila actions) and lower the EDF control to 0 in a province, you unlock the liberation mission. Upon completing the liberation mission, the province is liberated and EDF soldiers in the province dissapear. You also need to salvage scrap to get upgrades and new weapons from the Safehouse. In my opinion, the only upgrades you truly need are Level 2 Armour, Nano Ammo and safehouse fast travel.Weapons: There are quite a few weapons in the game, but I only ended up using 3 of them, those 3 being the Sledgehammer, Enforcer and NanoRifle. The sledgehammer is...Well, a sledgehammer, it destroys stuff and will one hit kill most enemies. The Enforcer is simple a SMG that shoots homing rounds with low damage, and the Nanorifle is a gun that vaporizes stuff.Multiplayer: This game has multiplayer, but I've never gotten into a multiplayer game, so I can't tell you if it's worth your time.Overrall: Great game, A clear 10/10 for me.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												I went into this game not having very high expectations, and what I got just blew me away. This is some of the best fun I've ever had with a computer game. Mind you, the story is not very detailed, there are some characters that you simply won't care about as they drop in and out of the story and in most cases that would be enough to turn me away. But when you look past the dull story, cardboard cutout characters and the rest, you will see something beautiful. Just try it out and see for yourself. This is an intense, pulse pounding action game that'll have you roaring with laughter the first time you drop a gunship into a building full of troops and see the rubble come down on their heads. The destruction is just glorious. The backdrop of a revolution is quite interesting, although as I stated earlier the story is bland.Trust me, just play this game.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												Most fun I've had blowing stuff up, driving into stuff, crashing into stuff, whacking stuff, knocking over stuff... you get the point. Pros: -Intriguing story, makes you want to finish the game-Extremely realisitc physics*-All buildings are destructible, sometimes I go into a new world and turn on the cheats and blow everything to pieces with the thermobaric rocket... what fun!-Easy to use controls-Open world enviroment, work on the main storyline or complete minor guerrilla actions-Blowing stuff to pieces, who doesn't enjoy that!-Runs REALLY good on low end machines if you turn down the graphics. My laptop barely gets any framerates in most games, like Garry's Mod or TF2, but this game, even with super low graphics settings blew my expectations out of the park, well still looking amazing. I can't even boot up Call of Duty: AW on lowest settings, this game got me 60+. Very well optimized.Cons: -*The physics on buildings are extremely realisitc, as long as the building/piece isn't connected to the ground in some way. A giant building can be supported by a single framing wall. No, not a reinforced steel pillar, not a metal frame, but just wall material. Not even concrete. So we are talking about a multi ton building being kept up by a single piece of plaster on the edge of the buliding. GG. As soon as you hit this plaster, the building falls and looks amazing. Overall 9.5/10. I enjoyed the heck out of the free weekend, and finished the main story in about 10 hours. It will probably take you another 10 hours to finish the rest of the guerilla actions, as well as another 24 hours to complete/mess around with all the other gamemodes. And for 4 dollars on sale, it's nice and cheap. I recommend.tl dr; blowing stuff up is fun m8 buy this

Posted: February 13
												I played this to completion back when it first came out and didn't particularly enjoy it then. I thought Id pick it up cheap in the sale and give it another go, I really shouldn't have bothered.The game has 3 core mechnics, blowing♥♥♥♥♥♥up, driving and shooting. It gets every single one of them wrong.The blowing stuff up engine is probably the least broken in that it can create some pretty good mayhem, but bears little resemblence to anything based in actual physical modeling and can be very frustraiting when a multi-story building is somehow being held up by a single steel beam. All the cars suffer from jello-suspension and handle like cruiseliners, yet are content to move at mach-3. And the gunplay is just flat out cookie-cutter boring, nothing feels like it has any impact, and the enemies seem to alternate at random between being bullet sponges and dropping at the meerest hint of a graze.There's also a tendency for swarms of enemies to roll up out of no-where at the slightest hint of you having fun; combine this with no real stealth options other than hiding in pipes and you've got for one great big bland mess.The game has a story, of which I have some very vauge recollection of the broad strokes, however it clearly left no lasting impression.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												Like Armageddon, it has good graphics, great controls, cool weapons, ability to wreck almost the entire environment, and cool weapons. Although Armageddon has way better graphics and is optimized much better. This game lags if there is a ton of stuff  being torn down around me, Armageddon does not lag ever. Armageddon is linear and this game is more of an open world type game, but still mission and objective based so it doesn't make much sense to randomly explore the open world because it is a waste of time since you need to do missions and side missions and blow up points to get a good amount of salvage and push back the enemy to advance the game. It is a pretty good game and is a lot of fun, but it does have some crappy problems.The biggest problem is that it has some of the worst sound I have ever heard in a game. The voices sound very tinny like in Half-Life 1, and all sounds in the game are very low quality, however HL1 has way better sounds than this garbage. The sound is ♥♥♥♥ing horrible.Their idea of a challenge and the only real hard aspect of the game is that you can be doing very well on a mission then out of nowhere you are swarmed with guys and you die very easily so you are going to see game over a lot. Just a little dmg and I am dead so I have to be really careful always.Vehicle control blows. My vehicle constantly takes way more dmg on missions than it should from the enemy because of the sucky vehicle controls. I am always ramming into rocks or buildings and coming to a dead stop which then allows the enemy to wail on me until I get going again, or flipping over/flying into things because vehicle jumping is very floaty. It is pretty much a problem with turning: for some reason, keyboard acceleration seems to be on when driving, so after holding left or right to turn for more than a second, it speeds up the turn and you instead of taking a turn smoothly, smash sharply into the left or right side wall.Game is not well optimized. Lags like a son of a ♥♥♥♥♥ when a large building is being demolished around me. Armageddon never lags and it is a newer game.Every time I alt+tab out of the game then go back, it is in a full screen window and I have to press alt+enter to get it back to regular full screen. Not a big problem though because I tend to not alt+tab out of games that much.If it were better optimized and had better sound it would be a 8.5/10 but I give it 7.5/10. Armageddon may be more linear than this but that does not take away from its fun factor in any way at all. Even though this game came first, I highly recommend playing Armageddon before you get this.Sound 4/10Game 7.5/10

content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												OMG, where has this game been all my life.One of the most underrated games ever.This game does things that other games should do, but can't do them, because they are lazy, don't know how, and it's easier to do the "basic" than something cool like this.In all honest, this game truly set the NEW standards but like I said, it's easier to pretend it doesn't exist and keep making crappy linear FPS's.SO, best way to describe this game, is like GTA meets Just Cause meets Total Recall (the 90s one with Arnold on Mars) meets some kind of destruction/demolition simulator.You can destroy about 99% of all structures in the game, in ridiculously fine, meticulously detail, with gravity helping you.Seriously, you can smash a wall with a your default weapon, which is an awesome, stylish sledgehammer, and put a hole and crack in it, bend pieces, and if you keep pounding, you'll bash out part of the wall. You can take your time smashing everything thing to bits.There is NO "hit the wall and whole wall disappears" no, rather, small to medium pieces slowly break off and fall due to gravity into a pile on the ground. You can knock out the support beams, and watch the whole building come crashing down.  The floors might have offices, bathrooms, data centers, or might be a shopping market with shelves of products, etc.But if you knock out the support beams and other supportingp arts, it will start to creak and make sounds, shake, become unstable, and a couple more hits, THE WHOLE THING CRASHES down.It's like watching videos of buildings being demolished, but in a game.You can be in combat, and there's like 10 guys on one floor shooting at you.You can fire rockets and they explode realistically inside, causing realistic damage.Maybe you are a 2nd floor and enemies on the 3rd floor? You can shoot the floor out beneath them and make them fall through.Or you need to make a quick escape? You can shoot out the floor under you and drop through.The game is GTA like in that there is a "living" world of people driving and going about their business, and you have various quests to deliver this, get this hear, some of them timed (which suck). You can get vehicles, run around, do whatever. The world is Mars, and the game world is divided into several large areas you can travel too seemlessly (just a couple areas must be unlocked due to the main quest).The game is like Just Cause 2 in that you are up against an evil government that has bases, outposts, and centers all over an area. The more you destroy their assets, the more they "lose control", the more your support builds up. The game has main-story quests, but tons of side-quests and things to do.You generally have to reduce the enemy's control in an area before opening up the next (again, you can still go there to some, but will be harder).You can take down their control however. You can attack however.There is no fixed way to do things. You can get some bombs, ram through the gates, detontate them. Or you can perch on a large hilltop or rooftop and fire rockets at them from afar, slowly damaging them and lowering their control. You can then come back later and finish the job or go do something else.It's like GTA where once you start mayhem, there is a meter that rates how "wanted" you are, so the security forces start to chase you, but if you can get away and hide.The game has dynamic type events you can participate in, as if the whole war is going on without you, and you can choose to go help your side in a battle or not.So, imagine Just Cause 2 meets GTA but you can destroy all the buildings, bridges, etc. completely in those games, and then pick up the salvage from them to use as currency.The whole free-to-do-it-however is the biggest plus, and you'll never get tired of demolishing the game world. After you beat the game, you can keep playing to with increased difficulty, with all your unlocked items and stuff, so that was cool.The only bad, is I wish nothing had to be unlocked. I beat the game and the later vehicles, like tanks and aircraft, I only start able to be using them right at the end, which is bullcrap if you ask me.And, I wish the game world was even bigger (it was pretty big, I just wanted more!), and lastly, mostly, that they did more games like this.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												RF: Guerrilla is an open world action game set in Mars, which is controlled by the Earth Defense Force. The main character joins the Red Faction resistance after the introduction/tutorial level and the goal of the game is to free Mars from the tyranny of EDF.Gameplay is pretty standard 3rd-person shooter, but the twist is the destructible environment. The ground isn't destructible but all buildings etc. can be destroyed. There are also vehicles to drive around, but most of them are quite slow and not that fun to drive around in. The story progresses through missions, which aren't very long or even that innovative. There are also several side missions available, but they repeat the same pattern and get tedious very quickly. The story isn't very good either.Difficulty-wise the game is kinda hard, because you die quite quickly even on normal and it takes some time for the health to regen. However, you could just go to a vehicle for a few seconds, which regens your health quite quickly. You also run out of ammo for the weapons very quickly and then you have to pick up one of the enemies' weapons or resort to the melee weapon. Alternatively you could go to an ammo crate, but those are sparsely scattered around the world and they don't even have that much ammo in them.There is a small upgrade system in the game, which can be used to buy a few new weapons and then some upgrades to them. The "currency" in the game is salvage, which can be obtained by destroying EDF buildings, completing missions or by mining ore deposits. I would imagine that people, who like to roam around the world and just do random stuff, would enjoy the game more, but I don't really enjoy doing that so I didn't have that much fun playing the game. The game is best played in short bursts, because there isn't much to do in the game unless you really like destroying virtual buildings. I finished the game in about 13 hours and I did about 45 of the 104 side missions the game has. The main story doesn't take that long to beat, but you must do some side missions for each area before the final story mission for the area unlocks.It's just an average open world action game that isn't much fun to play.  It also has GFWL, which can cause problems for some people. No longer has GFWL.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2015
												This game should have been really cool.  Should have been.  Basically think of a very basic Grand Theft Auto set on Mars.  Throw in completely destructible buildings for the scrap-based currency of the game, and a halfway decent story.  What could go wrong?  A lot, apparently.  First of all, in spite of the fact that the Mars settlements are huge, there's actually not a whole lot to do.  There are 8 different kinds of side missions apart from the story missions, but really they're just permutations of each other.The combat is brutal.  Endless waves of enemies can and will appear during higher alerts, and while the AI is somewhat decent, they will chew through your character no  matter how many armor upgrades you buy (there are only two).  Coupled with a bad or non-existent checkpoint system during many missions should give you more than a handful of moments of blinding rage.  And when you finish the game?  The difficulty ramps up more, and there's nothing you can do about it.  The scrap system could have sold the game by itself, if implemented properly.  Blow up or wreck stuff with a sledgehammer and collect the scrap.  This could have lead to an intricate crafting system, or at least really good upgrades, but the game has neither.  90% of the upgrades are useless, and are the fundamental reason the combat is so difficult.  No matter how many upgrades you buy, the game is just determined to be an as*hole.  What should have been the spinal column of the game winds up being nothing more than a gimmick.  Inexplicably, MANY buildings and structures drop no scrap at all, even if they're made entirely of metal.  So, the game won't even let you grind for the sorryass upgrades they give you. One of the areas the game fails painfully is once you liberate a district, any missions you left aside are cut off until the end of the game.  While a district is still active, many buildings belonging to the EDF yield scrap, and bonus morale with a decrease in control.  While the buildings are still there after liberation, they no longer have bonuses, and are the same as any other structure.  They were very proud of the destruction systems they laid into the game.  It doesn't happen often, but there are times when structures absolutely should NOT be still standing.  I once had a bridge with absolutely zero supports except at one end, and the godda*n thing just would NOT fall.  This can be problematic because demolition is the target of many of the game's missions, and the EDF aren't just going to sit there and watch you wreck their stuff.  The satchel charges you are given never seem to become powerful no matter how many points you dump into upgrading them.  So do things blow up?  Yes.  In an epic way?  No, not really.  There is a social system in place.  As you raise a district's morale, you gain an increased likelihood of random guerrillas joining you in battle.  They are unfortunately completely underpowered, fragile, and won't even follow you into vehicles.  There is also no system in place to take them on raids or recruit them yourself.  You are a one man army the entire game, even when you shouldn't be.  Believe it or not, the most interesting feature of the game is the vehicles.  There are quite a few of them with some very interesting designs.  The game ruins even this with horrid driving  mechanics.  Mars has 38% of the gravity of the Earth, so I assume for this reason the cars tend to slide everywhere like they're on god*amn ice skates, but it still ruins the experience of driving.  Everything else about the design of the game is bland and forgettable.The story is decent, by which I mean "not terrible like the rest of the game".  You might be inclined to suffer for the sake of the story, but in general the whole game is flat.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2013
												Grand Theft Auto: Mars is one of those games you hear a lot of good things about, then when you finally play it for yourself it leaves an odd taste in your mouth.  It has some good points and bad, and the result feels rather mediocre to me.The thing that this game does best is the destruction.  After all, that's what Red Faction is known for so it better be good.  It's a much more dynamic system than a game like Battlefield 3, allowing you to take out building supports and even collapse upper floors of multistory buildings to collapse the lower floors.  It's also a hell of a lot more fun than the chaos system in Just Cause 2 since you do more than shoot fuel tanks and throw grenades at satellite dishes.  Nearly everything is destructible and it's great fun running around destroying things.  Strangely though, hitting just about anything with a sledgehammer, even foot-thick metal barricades, causes them to splinter into pieces.  There are various explosives you can use as well, but their limited ammunition, even with upgrades, makes them of limited use.  Sometimes the best choice is to hijack a heavy APC, since those drive through buildings like there's nothing there.Driving works pretty well as well, though cars can be difficult to control in the low Mars gravity.  The vehicles themselves are rather unique, taking cues from various rover designs used by Nasa with some Volition style added.  You can find some really cool ones, though they pretty much all function the same.  Many vehicles have mounted weapons which auto-aim at enemies to help your destruction sprees.As for bad things, I found the alert system to be astonishingly annoying throughout the game.  The main way to advance through the game is to destroy EDF structures and do other missions that♥♥♥♥♥♥the EDF off.  When your alert level has raised up, they will constantly spawn near you with 10+ enemies shooting at you at all times, and they kill you very fast, even on normal difficulty.  This results on you being teleported a long distance to a safehouse and having to drive back to resume your task.  Dying during a mission seems to be completely random whether there's a checkpoint to retry from or whether you will have to restart the entire mission.  You will be doing that a lot.With this in mind, I found many of the side missions were designed to be quite annoying or very tedious.  There are vehicle recovery missions where you have to return a vehicle to a safe house.  The game always chooses one 2 sectors away so it takes you 4 or 5 minutes to drive there.  Other missions will put you at a ridiculous disadvantage such as requiring you to destroy 30 enemy vehicles on foot without dying.  I found these side missions so annoying that I just skipped as many as possible.The story is decent, though not terribly well presented.  It is advanced through short story mission briefings and a couple cutscenes with reasonable voice acting.  It's broken up into very rigid sections, where you progress through each sector of the map in sequence.  I never really got a feel for the characters which is unfortunate because they could have been done a lot better.Overall, while running around destroying things is fun, I feel like the rest of the game falls a bit flat.  It's fun, but the frustrating parts really get in the way.

												I really wanted to like this game. I really did. Pros:+Looks pretty nice+Micheal Bay's wet dream in terms of explosions per minute.+Fully destructible environment+Cool vehicle designs+Some interesting weapons that may have been done better elsewhere+Fairly difficult.Cons:- Controls feel sluggish. - Missions and Guerilla Actions are tedious and repetitive.- Story is dumb as hell- Driving feels off, not really sure how else to phrase it- Cover mechanics in a fully destructible enviroment are kinda dumb- Game world is neither interesting nor varied- Game was released in 2009 and still has infinitely respawning enemies (depending on alert level)- not just driving up in vehicles, but appearing from around a corner.- Action does not feel fluid, nor does shooting. It all feels very sluggish and disjointed.I guess this game is comparable to Far Cry 2: It's  got a lot of really cool ideas and engine features, but the game itself is nothing more than a vehicle for the developer to demonstrate that stuff. I feel like "The Saboteur" or Just Cause 2 are similar games that are much, much better as actual games.

												While it's a rather fun game, I can't recommend it in it's current state. The destruction is amazing, and it's a ton of fun to bring down a massive building with nothing but Thor's hammer and a few charges. However, it is not a ton of fun dealing with the damn near broken WIndows LIVE overlay that you MUST be signed into to even save your game, or the game breaking glitches I encountered in the first five minutes of starting up the game. After fighting with Windows LIVE for a while, I finally got signed in. When I went to edit my display settings, I couldn't set the resolution of the game for whatever reason. Ignoring this for the time being, I started it up and got into the game itself. Every model and texture was popping in and out like mad, making the game pretty much unplayable. After a Google search and adding a few things to Launch Options in Steam, I finally got it working. However, while the fixes were simple enough, this was a lot of hassle to simply make the game playable. If you're willing to take the time to screw around with Windows LIVE and work out any glitches you may run into, it's a good time, but if you're not willing to deal with the hassle, you'd best look elsewhere.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2016
												This is basically a Free roam game after the tutorial. You can do random missions that come along like protecting a village with a lot of guards. The E.D.F are out to kill you and its all about survival. You can get many different weapons like disintergrating weapons, Rocket launchers, Sledgehammer (Shammer) and Assault rifles and even more! It's all about destruction and blowing up buildings. The physics are absoultely AMAZING! You can bash all the supports of a building or warehouse and with nothing keeping it up, it will collapse. However, some of the building disappears and looks like it is sinking into the ground. There are cars, turrets and later on in the game jetpacks! It is amazing and fun to play. But lets get to the pros and cons of this game. Pros: Awesome PhysicsVariety of weaponsDifferent Car SpeedsTripods are usableBreaking GlassSmashing into housesKilling E.D.FLooks like a massive mapFree roam / Open WorldSide missions / random raid missionsDestruction Races Cons: No zoomed in aim systemLimit of charges early in the game (2 / 3)Less healthNo cover systemNot many weapon casesFeels like a small map while drivingDo i recommend this game? Yes. But buy it in the sale if you are not too keen on Open World and Getting a shammer and smashing walls down and people.  Game donated by:  Smiley  10/10 Y.A

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Before reading my review, you have to know that I never played the first two Red Faction, and I played Guerrilla after GTA 4 so yes, I will compare the two on many levels.And with that, let me say that personally I found Guerrilla to be really boring and uninspiring. The story is forgettable, every place looks the same (miles and miles of empty red desert and occasionally some building which looks like it was made in Halo 3's forge mode), few weapons, repeating missions, enemies and vehicles which all look alike and the shooting, man the shooting, is so inaccurate that it just made me angry everytime I had to use a gun.Honestly, Guerrilla had all the right card to become a great sci-fi game in my mind, I expected crazy futuristic weapons and vehicles, a deeper story, huge futuristic cities and something out of the "ordinary" sci-fi game, but no, it tries so hard to be serious and realistic that it forgot that GTA is also crazy and stupid and that's fun. And yes, I do understand that a big part of the game is the destructable buildings which you can literally demolish to the ground with a hammer and yes that is something that no other game has and I had fun with it but, after a while, it all felt repetitive, and while I was glued to the monitor while playing GTA4, I had to force myself to play Guerrilla, hoping for something new to happen.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												Just Cause 2 on Mars, but half the fun! You'll notice from all the videos that the development team really wants to highlight the demolition aspect of their game. They should! It's easily the best part. If the game just involved smashing empty buildings, a modern update of Blast Corps, it would be great.Unfortunately, it's cushioned by a bunch of cliched game elements that are laughably half-baked. You're regular Joe who gets caught up in a revolution because his brother is killed and blah blah blah. There are some other characters, but they're all just waiting for you in their stock roles when you get recruited. The controls aren't particularly intuitive and the environments are bland. The 3rd-person shooting feels about as sophisticated as GTA 3, with some half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ rarely working cover mechanics.Ultimately the game would be stronger if there were less of it. Get rid of the underdeveloped aspects and focus on the old-world destruction and this could have been a classic.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												A revolution of moronic AI is not a revolution worth fighting. Red Faction: Guerrilla has not aged well, particularly in its now asinine morale system in which everyone on Mars blames you for every civilian casualty; regardless of if they randomly chose to rally to your aid while you tried to hit and run against the EDF, or were simply ran over by a panicking driver while the future bullets began to fly. Volition does better work in creating destructive environments when they don't hinder or punish the player as they come to pieces like in Saints Row.Outside of an archaic single player riddled down with offensively large collect-a-things and lackluster rewards in the Mother Of All Bombs explosive said time wastes unlock, the most pleasure someone could derive from Guerilla is in its multiplayer. However, that is like saying being drunk can make you temporarily happy; a buzz only lasts as long as the intoxicant, or in this case people, hang around. And as this game only had a spike in player base because of finally becoming steamworks only AND cheap holiday sales, be aware that the current MP population will most likely dwindle within several months, if not weeks.

												All it takes is one bad day.After the death of his brother, Talion Dewittleads the Golden Path Red Faction resistanceagainst the corrupt EDF-ATLAS PMC.Strike back against the governmentand unleash your inner anarchist that every 17-year-old girl makes bad judgment calls on before she grows up with the ultimate marriage between gameplay mechanics which consist of:-Resident Evil 4's camera!-Grand Theft Auto's open world!-Gears of War shooting! (If you squint)-Includes Mjolnir! -Destruction 2.0!-Protagonist looks like that guy from Silent Hill Homecoming! (But in space!)-Value for money! -GFWL is dead!-If you haven't noticed all the references todifferent games, TROY BAKER!Unfortunately, I cannot even call the story a "good by-the-numbers" story, falling short ofthe original Red Faction, yet still being better than Red Faction II and that godawful Red Faction Armageddon.The world is so... boring? The opening actsrush you through the motions and then you'reoff doing the fetch-quest-of-the day that doesn't even feel as inspiring as the entire first act of the original Red Faction, and mind you, Red Faction's first mission was waaaaaaay more engaging than whatever was in Guerrilla's first act itself.I cannot recommend this game to anybody,even with the Steamworks port. I'm so sorry, everybody.If Talion Dewitt could remember his pastbefore coming to Mars, he'd rather have itmultiple choice.After all... all it takes is one bad day. content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												This game does not deserve the B rating that Meta Critic gave it. There is so much wasted potential that it is hard to know where to begin with this review.Pros:1) Weapon combinations can vastly change how you tackle a mission. Things can get interesting in the middle of a firefight when the only thing that you have left to fight with is a batch of remote bombs and a sledgehammer.Honestly, that is about it for the pros.Cons:1) The game is very buggy. Items pop on and off the screen all the time, including parts of your hero. When driving, the constant popping in and out of other vehicles on the road can lead to all sorts of problems, particularly when you are doing a timed mission. I was killed several times due to all the enemies on screen suddenly disappearing and yet they could still shoot me to pieces. Vehicles that you are driving will suddenly come to a complete stop or bounce all over the road, with no apparent reason as to why.2) The weapons, outside the Grinder, are nothing short of flat.3) The path indicator delights in taking you through the most complex and longest route it can find. I learned very quickly not to trust it.3) The challenges get ridiculous at times. The transporter missions, especially if you follow the path indicated, are all but impossible for a mortal being. Even if you find short cuts, the difficultly of the missions will make your blood pressure rise to unhealthy levels.When it comes to the destruction challenges, things get even more irritating. When a building has no roof, walls, or supports still intact, I consider it destroyed. There were too many times where a challenge would not end because two pieces of concrete were still stacked on top of each other somewhere in the pile of rubble and the game considered the building still standing.4) The much-lorded physics and destruction engine needs some major overhauls. I’m no structural engineer, but when I see a four story building being held up by one support in the corner of the structure as if by magic it becomes plain that they need to tune up their system. There were several times when I would try to level structures only to have random sections remain hovering in the air.5)  Driving in the game is a major chore due to the horrible driving characteristics of the vehicles and  physics. To top it off, the game forces you to drive far too much due to poor mission and world design.I cannot recommend this game. They were pushing for a GTA or a Saints Row with lots of explosions and destruction as the selling point and they missed the mark.

												So if you read my other reviews you'll see that I praised the freedom in Just Cause 2 and Saints Row 3, but prepare for something completely over the top. This game doesn't have the ridiculous of Saints Row 3 or the parachuting and grappling hook freedom of Just Cause 2, but what it does have is a completely destructible environment. You can go around destroying anything in sight, but if you really want to take it to the next level you can. It's a lot of fun and I highly recommend you check it out.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												Truly a game that was based in part on the GTA series from playstation, but far better, far funner, and a plotline! It isn't just about killing random people and escaping the police...though it can be. Basically it is a worthwhile play/purchase if you enjoy GTA 3, Vice City, etc. Plus YOU GET TO DESTORY EVERYTHING, checkpoint? bam roll through the block house, taking cover? run it and them over, sniping from that tall building? place some bombs and wack it with you hammer and down they come. It is not very linear in gameplay you can actually destroy places before you have a mission there, which is a small drawback since once you have the mission the buildings reappear but elsewise once destroyed it stays destroyed. The world changes with your destructive presence, along with news updating as you progress, which is a feature from the first game with the wanted posters updating as you progress. It has a science fiction plotline that takes place on Mars and has socialist undertones; workers rights to the means of production! or really rather just freedom from their oppessors, cause who cares about Mars politics just kill and destroy. And you become their champion all while killing, salvaging, and destroying from a 3rd person viewpoint. Carries on the storyline from the two previous games, which are similar in the sense that you are overthrowing the oppessors, I'll admit I never did play the 2nd game. Don't worry, though, if you never played the first two games; this one has enough activity and an imersive story-world to be a standalone, now if only the 4th one was as good.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2011
												Let's talk 3rd person sandbox destruction on the biggest literal sandbox of all: Mars. You play Alec Mason, hammer-wielding badass and walking instrument of devastation and vengance with an apparent grudge against every sign of human habitation on mars. You can, and will, smash many, many things to pieces in your time on the red planet, and the addition of a variety of fun weapons only make it more fun, especially when you start to harrass the EDF. Alec can and will handily snap necks with a single swing of his axe and crush vehicles with a few easy slams, but add explosives, bullets, and lots of exotic toys into the mix, and watch the chaos. Or, better yet, start some. The only way this could be more fun would be if it had Prototype-style dismemberment, Just Cause-style fast travel, and Red Dead Redemption-style do-what-the-hell-you-want minigames. On its own, it's a great, cathartic panalopy of destruction.

												I got this game for $1.99 on a sale so I can't complain too much. I have played this on console a bit and was quite excited to see the PC version at such a heavy discount. Regardless, I can't reccomend this to anyone, whether it's on sale or not.Cons:1. Windows Live - It makes you create a Windows Live account before playing. You do have the option to play offline, but multiplayer is impossible this way.2. Lag - This may not effect everyone, but people with mid to low end PCs should be wary. Even after setting the graphics and resolution as low as it can be, I would still never get over 15 fps, much less when destroying something.3. Graphical Issues - Immediately upon starting the game, my character's coat began flying around like crazy and eventually just gave up and dissappear. After getting a kick out of that, I walked around the first level and everything began blinking in and out of existence. "See that tower? No you don-- Oh, there it is! Wait nevermind..." This would happen with everything from structures to weapons, to my body (oddly enough however, not my clothes)4. Other Glitches - I had a controller plugged in and initially could not move my body, only my camera, with either my keyboard or controller. I researched this problem online and apparently it is quite common, although no one had a fix. I ended up exiting and unplugging my controller and surprise, surprise, I began to move.Pros:1. Destructible Environment - Breaking everything was quite satisfying, even though I sensed my GPU was ready to burst into flames when ever something would fall down.2. Good Physics - Self explanatory.Final Conclusion:If you have a PC gifted to you from the gods, and want to break some virtual buildings with a sledgehammer, buy this game. If either one of those things does not apply to you, stay away from this game.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												I found Red Faction Guerrilla to be quite entertaining. Just the fact you're on a very large open world of Mars with quite different sectors and really cool graphics that transition through the night and day was interesting in itself. It pretty much plays like a loose RPG, gathering supplies/vehicles with a GTA sort of mode. The overall theme is also pretty well done as you take on the evil government scumbags. You can hear about how you're such an evil terrorist on the propaganda radio network. This is a great game for those who like to 'fight for the people' or 'rebel alliance' sort of feel against the empire against all odds. The vehicles are pretty neat as well.Of course, the destruction is the BEST. It totally surpasses the garbage that passes for 'destruction' in BF3, despite it being a few years older, and by extension any other game that claims destruction that I know of. Every single peice of a building can be hacked away, you can use explosive charges set in a sequence...which when used on tall buildings might remind one of the scenes of the WTC towers falling on 9/11...hint hint. As well as use other interesting weapons to create destructive effects like implosion nukes.The only bad parts of this game were some hokey scenes, a few bugs that sort of hampered a full RPG experience (vehicles you stole not being at the base you put them at) and some AI issues here and there as well as the GFWL drm but that can be surpassed with an offline account and such.

												This game was definitely worth the money. With a wide open world, and impeccabely destructible enviroment, this game is superbly fun. Three main things help to highlight the reason I enjoy this game: 1.) As I mentioned before, the world around the player is superbly destructible. And it isn't like any other game with a destructible enviroment (i.e Battlefield 4, Crysis 1, Mercenaries 2), in Red Faction Guerrilla, you can demolish entire houses, and  give yourself tactical advantages. The destructible enviroments just help to add immersion to the game.2.) The A.I oppistion is extremely smart, and very deadly. They actually pose a major threat, as compared to other open world games with weaker enemies (i.e Just Cause, Just Cause 2, Dead Island). This makes players think about how to demolish certain objects surrounded by enemies.3.) The graphics are pretty damn good for a 2009 game. The particle effects, along with shadowing and textures are very detailed.

												Basically - A great way to kill a few hours, but unless you play multiplayer there's not a lot of drive to play it again.PROS:1. Free therapy for destructive urges2. A nice "david vs. goliath" feeling as the game progresses3. graphics are nice for release date4. takes the moderately reduced gravity into account5. nice destructive physics on some objects. Always a nice feeling to take out some EDF equipment.6. The dump truck + RammingCONS:1. typically clunky third-person game driving physics, though some of that is using a keyboard2. friendly AI are apparently suicidal, both in enemy fire and when trying to get in a vehicle and drive3.  You can only drive so far, confront an oncoming theat, keep driving, then drive some more so many times before it becomes repetitive. A quick-leap system would be nice, even if it made the game dramatically shorter.4. Can't think of a real reason to go back and play it again. It may be a go-to when a sledgehammer comes to mind, but the central storyline and interception missions just don't hold up for full storyline replays.

												Finished this game many years after release and would gladly play it again. It has one of the most satisfying destruction engines ever created and it boggles the mind why other games haven't used it. I would play it again simply to wreak havoc on structures with triggered explosives. It would be great if everything wasn't so red and sparse, but i suppose at the time, the lack of foilage and in game detail was to keep the framerates at a high level due to the physics calculations taking place in the destuction engine. Plus ..it was Mars. A fantastic game and the franchise is sorely missed here.

Posted: October 15, 2011
												This game is ♥♥♥♥ing AWESOME!  It's like GTA + Total Recall + Destroy All Humans, mixed with a little Fallout.  And that's not to mention all the elements the devs came up with on their own.  I'm at the 20 hour mark and demolishing entire buildings using only my banhammer of the gods was just starting to lose it's charm when suddenly the game gives me A JETPACK!  I haven't even started destroying buildings with the missile launcher(THE 3RD UNLOCKABLE) and the game gives me A JETPACK!  It's so refreshing to see game devs remembering that games are supposed to be FUN and they got it right with this one.  I could go on forever about all the great things in this game and how other games could have benefited if they did some copying so instead I'll just list the 3 big complaints; ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ friendly NPC AI, destroyed buildings remaining destroyed and Mason's buggy coat.  It can be assumed that anything else is ether average or better(usually better) so if you like sandbox games, get this one.
